PETITION.TITLE: Company Tax Collection System
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:

The Government's Budget decision to change the company tax collection system will be a crippling blow to many small businesses, already suffering as a direct result of the Hawke Labor Government's high interest rate policy.
The earlier remittance of company tax payments to the Government will substantially reduce the cash-flow position of thousands of small businesses.

Many small businesses will be driven under as a result of the Government's decision-unable to find funds for both tax commitments and new stock, only able to borrow at record high interest rates and unable to claim any tax relief on such borrowings to meet their tax commitment.
The Government's proposed changes to the company tax collection system has only been introduced as a greedy grab for more tax revenue.

The small business community would prefer the Government to completely abandon the proposal rather than make only minor alterations to the original Budget decision, which are not likely to alleviate the situation to any significant extent.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: X-rated and Violent Video Material
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate assembled in Parliament.
The petition of citizens of Australia points out:

That all State Governments, State Attorneys-General, most womens' groups and the majority of men in Australia, including significant numbers of Members of Parliament, are totally opposed to the importation and distribution of `X' and excessively violent `R'-rated video pornography in Australia.
That most `X'-rated material available in Australia is imported.
That the Federal Government, by its Customs power under the Constitution, and not the A.C.T. Government, is solely responsible for controlling the importation of this pornographic material.
That by continuing to allow the importation of such pornographic material, the Federal Government is neglecting its responsibility to the women, children and families of Australia.
Your petitioners, therefore, request the Senate to:
1. Ban `X'-rated pornographic material at the point of entry into Australia.
2. Exclude from the `R'-rating all gratuitously violent material.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Health Care for the Elderly
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
We the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:
Australia's population is ageing and most people require more health services as they grow older.
if open not-for-profit health funds are to be able to meet the costs of providing benefits to their older members at affordable rates, they need to share these costs equitably.
some health insurance organisations are being allowed to avoid meeting the health costs of sick and elderly people.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled, urge the Government to,
Take the necessary action to reverse rising cost trends and provide positive incentives to encourage all health funds to share the cost of health care for sick and elderly Australians.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Medicare: Abortions
PETITION.PARA: The Honourable President and members of the Senate assembled in Parliament. This petition of the below citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the Senate that we support the continued cover for all abortions on the Medicare schedule. We oppose any attempt to restrict access to the rebate under Medicare.

Medicare cannot pretend to be a universal health care system without providing a rebate for a termination of pregnancy. Those who will be hardest hit by proposals to restrict access to items 6469, 274 and 275 on the Medicare schedule are poorer and disadvantaged women who will not be able to meet the cost of a non-subsidised abortion.
Your petitioners humbly pray and request that the Senate will vote against any attempt to restrict access to abortion or any abortion-related items on the Medicare schedule.

PETITION.TITLE: South-eastern Forests, New South Wales: Woodchipping Licences
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament.

The petition of the undersigned shows the concern to save the south east forest of Australia from the threat of logging and to ensure that the national heritage listing is extended to state heritage listing.

Your petitioners request that the Senate in Parliament assembled, stop the logging of the Coolungubra, Cathcart, Eagan Peaks and Tantawangalow State forests and to stop renewals of Harris Daishowa woodchip export licence and a total re evaluation of state forestry practices. We humbly request the Parliament to ensure that the south east forests are set aside for world heritage, and all petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: GENERAL PRACTITIONER ARRANGEMENTS: CONFIDENTIALITY OF PATIENTS' RECORDS

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the attention of the Minister representing the Minister for Community Services and Health been drawn to newspaper advertisements taken out by the Australian Doctors Fund (ADF) and the New South Wales branch of the Australian Medical Association (AMA) relating to the new general practitioner arrangements and headed in very large type, `Who's looking at your medical records?'? Can the Minister inform the Senate whether the claims made in the advertisements about the confidentiality of patient records under the new arrangements have any basis in fact?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —As Senator Giles has rightly explained, the advertisements headed `Who's looking at your medical records?' claim that under the new arrangements `confidentiality between you and your doctor will be lost forever' and that `Government agents' will be allowed to access patient records. They incite patients to tell their doctors not to become vocationally registered because they `don't want their medical records exposed'. It is hard to believe the depths of dishonesty plumbed by the New South Wales Australian Medical Association and the ADF both in these advertisements and in letters sent to doctors by the New South Wales AMA. The letter speaks of a need to caution all general practitioners (GPs) that `registration allows government agents to carry out random inspections of their medical records' and to `warn the public of New South Wales of the inevitable loss of confidentiality of their medical records if they attend a vocationally registered practice'.

ANSWER.PARA: I think these statements ought to be compared with the facts. It was an all-party Senate select committee which unanimously recommended-in a report welcomed by the AMA-that a special committee called the Descriptor Utilisation Review Committee should be developed jointly by government, the Royal Australian College of General Practitioners and the AMA to review the new arrangements. It said that the Committee believed that such a body could be structured to carry out its work without breaching patient confidentiality or the established ethics of the medical profession and recommended that it should consist of vocationally registered GPs chosen by their peers. The Senate select committee recommended that the development of this process should be put in the profession's hands and that the review process should not proceed without legislation or without the backing of the College and the AMA. It proposed the establishment of a working party representative of the Department of Community Services and Health, the College and the AMA to develop and finalise such a proposal for review. The AMA has already nominated two members for the working party, which is about to begin its consideration of that review process and what should be adopted.

The facts speak for themselves and were made clear to all GPs in a letter from the Health Insurance Commission and a pamphlet explaining the new arrangements. Thus, the spectre of `Government agents' exposing patients' confidential records to public scrutiny is a gross misrepresentation of the true position. It will be the medical profession itself, represented by the AMA and the College, which decides on how the review should take place. No decision has yet been made, nor will it be made until full consultation and public discussion has been completed.

In view of the seriousness of the situation, particularly the concern that the advertisement and the letter were designed to denigrate doctors seeking to become vocationally registered, Dr Blewett asked his Department to refer both the advertisement and the letter to the Medical Board of New South Wales for its consideration and whatever action is deemed necessary. He is also sending copies of this material to the Treasurer and others of his colleagues as further evidence that contributions to the Australian Doctors Fund should not be tax deductable in the light of the dishonest purposes for which such moneys are being applied. Unfortunately, fringe elements of the medical profession-the New South Wales AMA and the ADF-are making a last ditch attempt to impede historic reform of general practice. For political reasons, they do not want the Government and the medical profession to work together constructively for the benefit of patients and, it should be importantly stressed, for the benefit of the doctors.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask whether the Minister representing the Prime Minister and Treasurer is aware that on 28 October on Melbourne radio the Prime Minister said of interest rates:

Does that remain the Government's assessment of the outlook for interest rates? Given that they are causing so much suffering in the community for home buyers, small businesses and farmers, can the Minister say, if indeed rates have peaked, when they are likely to start coming down?

TALK.START.PARA: —I did not hear the Prime Minister on 28 October, but I do not doubt the veracity of the earlier part of Senator Lewis's question. I do not wish to make assessments about the likely outlook for interest rates. I have said on numerous occasions, in answer to numerous questions in the Senate at Question Time, that the current monetary policy stance of the Government will be retained until such time as excess demand in the Australian economy is reduced. There are plenty of signs of that happening now. The signs sometimes run ahead of the officially published statistics, which tend to lag. A judgment will have to be made about that. If there is such a judgment made, Senator Lewis will see the result of it at that time.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Why does the Minister lack the confidence of the Prime Minister to confirm the Prime Minister's prediction that interest rates will not go any higher? Is that because the Minister may have more recent information which casts any doubt on this prediction?

—It is a matter of style and personality. I have less confidence than does the Prime Minister about most things. As I said to Senator Stone the other day, these things are very subjective. I have no different information.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. I ask: What are the implications for Australian sugar producers of the decision by the United States to expand its sugar quotas by 21,000 tonnes or 13.5 per cent? What are the general short term and long term forecasts for that industry?

—I read an article in today's Australian newspaper by John Durie headlined `US expands sugar quota'. The United States has increased by 13.5 per cent its sugar import quota. The Australian share of that increase is 21,000 tonnes, which brings the Australian overall quota of sugar into the United states to 178,221 tonnes. Australia's fundamental problem is that under the United States sugar policy, high domestic support arrangements are propping up inefficient production and encouraging production, because of high prices, of alternative sweeteners in competition with sugar. In a recent General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade case GATT members, including the United States, agreed that the United States sugar import regime was in contravention of GATT rules. We have since been encouraging the United States to bring its sugar import quota system into conformity with GATT as soon as possible.

—I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Finance. In view of the swing against the Labor Government in the South Australian State election on Saturday and the claim by all political commentators that this resulted from high home and small business interest rates, will the Government reconsider its policy of deregulation of banks and finance institutions? Will the Government reconsider the original purpose for the creation of the Commonwealth Bank-created, I point out, by the progenitors of the present but very different Australian Labor Party-and re-establish firmer, if not exclusive, government control of credit creation?

—In some distant corner of this land there is a little party known as the Australian Democrats which had some minor success in South Australia at the weekend. That is the only part of the Western world where I think any government would consider the last part of Senator Coulter's question, which related to a much firmer control of all credit by governments. I think that is probably correct. Senator Coulter asked me whether the Government will reconsider its policies essentially of floating the dollar and deregulation of the financial sector. I think that unlikely. In so far as a different role for the Commonwealth Bank is concerned, as suggested by Senator Coulter, I think that unlikely too.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Is the Minister saying that it is not possible for the Government to take a firmer hold in an objective sense, or is he saying that, for political reasons, the Government will choose not to take a firmer hold of the matter of credit creation and the re-regulation of the banks and financial institutions?
—No, not for political reasons; for economic reasons.

—Can the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade give to the Senate any details of the political changes taking place in Czechoslovakia? In particular, what is his assessment of the likelihood of Czechoslovakia adopting a democratic multi-party system with free and fair elections?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The situation in Czechoslovakia is highly fluid. I do not think anyone could be confidently making any predictions about what will happen at this stage. But at this stage we understand that the following has happened. As has been reported, nine people were replaced in the Politburo at the Central Committee meeting on 24 and 25 November, including the General Secretary of the Communist Party, Milos Jakes. Mr Jakes was replaced by Karel Urbanek, Miroslav Stepan was sacked as Party Chief in Prague and, reportedly, the Prime Minister, Ladislav Adamec, refused to remain a member of the new Politburo, considering it resistant to reform. Of course, it is possible that further changes will occur in the next few days. In order to encourage that, demonstrations have been continuing daily since 17 November and, at most recent estimates, they have grown in size in Prague to about 600,000 people. Leading the crowds in Prague-as has been reported and as we all know-are leading Charter 77 dissidents, such as Vaclav Havel and the Prague Spring Leader, Alexander Dubcek. Demonstrators are calling for further political reforms and free elections. They have called for a two-hour general strike to take place today.

ANSWER.PARA: The unrest and pressure for reform in Czechoslovakia is, of course, an inevitable and logical part of the movement for change that is presently sweeping across eastern Europe. I am sure that the Prime Minister and I were simply reflecting public opinion in Australia, and indeed in the rest of the world, when we spoke out some days ago against the Czech Government's initial resistance to change and its use of the tactics of political repression. We certainly now welcome the increased responsiveness of the Czech Government to popular demand and note that this may be only the commencement of a process of fundamental reform. We certainly hope that it is. How far that process will go, I guess, will become clear in the next few days or, if it does not, I will be in a better position to assess it when I come back from visiting the area in the second half of December.

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy read a report in the West Australian on 22 November in which the Australian Bureau of Agricultural and Resource Economics has found that Western Australian prices for slaughtered sheep have fallen by 41.3 per cent since June? —This matter has come before the Senate several times in the form of a number of questions, including one from Senator Jenkins. I think the key aspect of the honourable senator's question is really related to trying to maintain the confidentiality of negotiations on a very sensitive matter, such as these negotiations with Saudi Arabia. I appreciate the honourable senator's interest in this matter. I do not make the automatic link that he makes: that the fall in prices in Western Australia, as plotted by the Australian Bureau of Agricultural and Resource Economics, is due solely to the current imbroglio with Saudi Arabia. Senator Panizza will be aware that this Government has pursued exhaustive lobbying efforts in Saudi Arabia in its own right and through the Australian Meat and Livestock Corporation. Those agents and merchants who ply the trade with Saudi Arabia have exercised their commercial contacts as well. The Prime Minister has written to the King of Saudi Arabia and at this stage we are awaiting a reply.

—I ask a supplementary question, Mr President. I thank the Minister for his reply on the latest position, but I ask: Bearing in mind the Government's generosity in another dispute which has affected some of the country-that is, the airline dispute-is the Government considering compensation to producers for loss of income?

—The Government sees no parallel at all between what has happened in the live sheep export trade in Saudi Arabia and the quite categorically different circumstances of the airline dispute. We are not making any such consideration.

—Has the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs seen the front page article in today's West Australian newspaper which reports a second outbreak of violence between rival bikie gangs in the Perth suburb of Swan View and a call from the Western Australian Minister for Police, Ian Taylor, that the offenders be deported? Has the Minister received any formal representations from Mr Taylor or the Western Australian police force for such deportations to be effected?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: IMMIGRATION, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not think I have received a formal approach, although there may have been some contact between my Department and the Western Australian Police Department. I have been made aware by press reports that a bikie group known as the `Mongrel Mob' has been involved in a feud with a rival gang in Western Australia. It is also alleged that many members of the Mongrel Mob are New Zealand citizens. However, I must point out that New Zealand citizens have the right of residence within Australia under the trans-Tasman agreement. This is subject to their not having a serious criminal record and having a New Zealand passport on entry. This concession is available to Australian citizens seeking residence in New Zealand. My Department has yet to check the entry details of the alleged members of the gang, but it would appear that no record of any serious criminal offences was held on their entry.

ANSWER.PARA: It is not up to a State government to deport anyone. That power lies only with the Federal government and, in particular, with the Minister for Immigration. However, New Zealand citizens may be deported if they commit a serious crime in Australia and come within the ambit of the Minister's criminal deportation policy, or if they are prohibited non-citizens by virtue of a prior serious criminal record or prior deportation from Australia. My Department is making further inquiries and will give me a report shortly.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. Can the Minister assure the Senate that imports of Canadian pork will be tested for residues of such carcinogens as carbodox and mecadox-two feed additives which have been banned for us in Australia since 1 January 1987 but which are still freely available to Canadian pork producers? If we are not testing for such residues, can the Minister explain why Australia continues such a subservient attitude in respect of primary industry to the extent that our exported beef, cheese and horticultural products all undergo rigorous testing in countries which import them while we fail to apply similarly tough testing for foodstuffs coming into Australia?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I cannot say at this stage whether those particular food additives are tested for. What I can say about uncooked Canadian pig meat, which is the subject of Senator Brownhill's question, is that the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service (AQIS) has satisfied itself that uncooked Canadian pig meat should not be discriminated against on the basis that it has a minimal risk of bringing into Australia transmissible gastroenteritis.
—Minimal? There should be no risk.

—I take the interjection because there has never been, in the period in which the honourable senator's Party has been in government or at any other time, a no risk policy on quarantine. There has always been a minimum risk policy. It is impossible to have a no risk quarantine policy, as anyone who pauses to think about how we would give such a guarantee will understand immediately. I will check to see whether residues of the food additives that were referred to are checked in quarantine. From a quarantine point of view, whatever standard and routine checks are done will be done in the normal course on this particular commodity. If it is a regular practice, as I understand it is, that all food coming into Australia is checked in some way for these additives, I imagine that uncooked Canadian pig meat is equally checked. I will get back to the honourable senator on the specific point.

ANSWER.PARA: What disturbs me about the question and about what I think is a campaign emanating from the Opposition about the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service is that the Australian Government--

TALK.START.PARA: —This is what you said on Friday.
—This is about a food additive which is banned in Australia.

—Yes, I know, but the honourable senator is referring to retaliatory trade actions by using quarantine as a non-tariff barrier to trade. The quicker he would come out and say that, the more honest the debate on this subject in Australia would be. It is not an occasion to denigrate the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service's very high standards of professionalism. What is essential is that quarantine laws in this country and the actions of our quarantine service be entirely understood by international trading markets as a strictly quarantine function. As I said on Friday-someone interjected about what I said then, but what I said on Friday obviously was not understood-no wool, wheat or beef producer, horticulturalist, or anyone who exports rural or agricultural commodities from this country will welcome the Opposition's trying to bring the AQIS into disrepute by attacks on its integrity, because our clients overseas will seize on that internal domestic ferment and use that to justify a preference for goods from other countries. If that line of approach takes root, I suggest that the honourable senator should pause, because the very rural base that he relies on for political support will turn on him and react against him directly.

ANSWER.PARA: While I am on the subject I might also add that it waxes very strange for an Opposition, which in its Economic Action Plan proposes notional cuts to the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service of $23m out of its Budget, to complain about the level of expertise in the Service. On the one hand it is trying to geld that service and make it ineffective by not providing sufficient budgetary allocations and on the other hand it is running around complaining about it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister for Consumer Affairs aware of a possible labelling problem associated with a particular infant formula called S26? If so, can the Minister say whether there is any risk to health arising from this problem, and what steps are being taken to protect the public?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is a problem with the labelling of a product called S26. At the outset I indicate that it is not a major problem, but every opportunity to warn parents is very eagerly seized upon at the moment. The problem arises from the fact that some cans have been mislabelled. The formula in those cans is intended for consumption by infants over the age of six months, but S26 itself is intended for infants of the age of six months or less. So it could be possible that some infants under the age of six months are getting the wrong product in cans marked S26.

ANSWER.PARA: I have sought some advice on the risk involved and also on the extent of the problem. That information is necessary in order to give a complete picture. I have been informed by a variety of experts from the Department of Community Services and Health and also paediatricians that the risk to any healthy infant is very low but that there is a risk involved to infants who are less than six months old, particularly those who have been ill or dehydrated during the course of consumption of the product. So, the risk can be targeted to ill or dehydrated babies below the age of six months. In terms of its extent, our information is that only a few cans are believed to have been mislabelled. The company has advised that it has undertaken an extensive search of all retail outlets and has recalled from those outlets the cans that it has been able to find. I have been informed on that basis that they are no longer available for sale. But it may well be that parents have bought S26 and are unaware of the risks that may be involved with it.

Another factor is that the formula has not been made available through hospitals, so parents of babies who have been born in hospitals or who have spent time in hospital can generally be sure that those babies will not be at risk. The company and I have agreed, however, that we need to make the public aware of the risk, no matter how minor or marginal it may be. To that extent, the company has been prompt in recalling the product and issuing statements and its performance needs to be acknowledged. I take a final opportunity to warn those parents with children under the age of six months, particularly those who may have been ill or dehydrated and who may have used formula S26, to desist from using the formula, to return the product to their retail outlet and also to take care with a child who may have consumed the formula.

TALK.START.PARA: —Will the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories confirm that a ministerial committee chaired by him was responsible for overturning the unanimous recommendation of an official assessment committee to award the new $2.4m contract for the Buy Australian-made campaign to Luscombe and Partners Pty Ltd and, instead, ordering that the account be given to the Australian Labor Party advertising agent, John Singleton? Can the Minister confirm that research done for the assessment committee by Reark Research Pty Ltd showed that the Luscombe and Partners campaign had a superior response to John Singleton's? Can the Minister tell me how much the Hawke Government has given John Singleton from public moneys since the 1987 election? Further, will the Minister tell the Senate why his Government maintains the farce of open and fair tendering for major consultancies when it will overturn the decisions of official assessment committees in order to award contracts to firms such as John Singleton, which is known to work for and on behalf of the Labor Party?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALK.START.PARA: —It is the job of officials to analyse and to recommend; it is the job of Ministers to decide. On this occasion, a recommendation was received-but not nearly in the stark terms in which Senator Bishop suggests. It was considered by a ministerial committee consisting of Senator Walsh, Mrs Kelly and me. The three of us unanimously resolved to award the contract to John Singleton Advertising, not because John Singleton worked for the Labor Party but because in our unanimous view-and I think even in retrospect it was the absolutely correct view-the concept of using John Williamson's theme of True Blue, which was accepted, incredibly well known and extremely popular, was the only way for us to go. We had a very limited budget. As honourable senators would know, $2.4m does not buy much on television these days. We decided that it was not enough money to establish a new concept and that it was far better to rely on the one we had. Given that that was a unanimous decision, there is no reason to question it.

ANSWER.PARA: In so far as research being done is concerned, research is being done by a lot of people and Singleton's agency can counter with a welter of research on True Blue's popularity and the enduring nature of that popularity. So far as open and fair tendering processes are concerned, we have them, and they will continue. As far as other money the Singleton agency has received from the Government is concerned, off the top of my head I cannot think of any but I will see what the Government has done.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Can the Minister enlighten us as to what criterion he uses to hold himself at arm's length from a person who is a personal friend and a political ally; indeed, that he may ensure that he gets value for money in accordance with the new finance regulations?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALK.START.PARA: —It is certainly true that John Singleton is a friend of mine, and he has been for a long time. Had I been making the decision on my own, perhaps the honourable senator would have a reason for standing up and asking her question. However, it would be very difficult to accuse Senator Walsh, firstly, of being a friend of John Singleton or, secondly, in any way being associated with his agency. I think the same would go for Mrs Kelly. The reality is that three Ministers examined the material and three Ministers came to the same decision and in my view it was absolutely correct.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade and relates to Myanmar, still better known as Burma. As the Minister is no doubt aware, there are continued reports of the massacre of civilians, including children, perpetrated by members of the Burmese armed forces in areas adjacent to the Thai-Burma border, as well as reports that the Burmese Army is concentrating troops in preparation for a major offensive against various ethnic groups, which will lead to an increase in refugee numbers. Given that around $65,000 is being spent monthly on supplying the basic needs of Karen refugees on the Thai side of the border, and another $15,000 a month is being supplied for the basic needs of the Burmese students who have taken refuge in border areas, there is still a shortfall, with some groups receiving little or no aid. I therefore ask the Minister whether the Australian Government will now urgently consider granting much needed humanitarian aid to the victims of this protracted civil war, thus supplementing the work of voluntary non-government organisations which are currently responding to requests for medical supplies, food supplements, blankets, mosquito nets and clothing.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Government is aware that the Myanmar military regime has been engaged in a long-running campaign against ethnic insurgencies on Myanmar's borders and that following suppression of the pro-democracy demonstrations in Yangon in September last year large numbers of students have taken refuge, as Senator Vallentine says, on the Myanmar-Thai border. The Government would certainly give sympathetic consideration to any request for aid which was clearly of an emergency and humanitarian nature. We urge the authorities in the countries-in fact on a number of other occasions we have done this publicly and privately-to create the conditions necessary for the students to be able to return to their homes, by responding to the widespread popular desire for democracy and political and economic reform in the country and for a political resolution of the ethnic insurgencies.

ANSWER.PARA: The Australian Government is convinced that the holding of a free and fair multi-party election must be an essential first step to any resolution of the problems facing the country and to the process of national reconciliation. In this context I might say that we very much welcome the announcement by the authorities in Myanmar that elections will be held on 27 May next year. Again, we urge Government authorities to lift the numerous and oppressive restrictions on political activity that are still in force, including in particular the detention of Aung San Suu Kyi and others in a political leadership role, which can only affect the credibility of that whole election process.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Science, Customs and Small Business. I asked him a question about the Gold Coast seaway some months ago. In view of the fact that the Australian Federal Police has claimed that the Gold Coast seaway is almost certainly being used for big-time drug running, will the Minister take steps to implement a full-scale customs and quarantine service for the port of Southport? The sole customs agent was transferred to Brisbane last year when the service could have been amplified by simply employing a quarantine officer to assist him. Lack of customs facilities is also harming the Gold Coast tourist trade as overseas yachts are forced to detour to either Brisbane or Coffs Harbour to obtain clearance. If the Minister has no intention of replacing the Gold Coast customs service and augmenting it with the quarantine service will he explain his reasons?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will have to obtain a detailed answer regarding this matter from the Minister for Science, Customs and Small Business. I recall that when I answered the question last time I think the view of the Australian Customs Service was that there were greater efficiencies in handling this matter in terms of intelligence gathering and if there were a suspicious situation which Customs felt it should investigate it would be best conducted from Brisbane, having regard to the improvement in the intelligence gathering capacity of Customs.

ANSWER.PARA: I think that was the gist of the answer that we gave last time. I will inquire whether that answer is still contemporary in the light of what the honourable senator has said in his question and provide him with an answer as soon as possible.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to you, Mr President. What weight of paper is used annually in the Senate and is any recycled paper processed by the Senate printing service? Are the printing machines presently in use capable of using high recycled content paper? If not, is it feasible to have these machines converted at a reasonable cost, or are you aware of any plans to develop Australian machinery capable of printing on a range of recycled papers? Finally, what arrangements exist for the recycling of the large quantities of paper discarded each day in the Senate?

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I am advised that the weight of fine cut and bulk bond paper purchased by the Department of the Senate in 1988-89 was approximately 80 tonnes. A small amount of both 80 per cent and 100 per cent recycled paper has been used by the Department to assess the capacity of the printing machinery to use the paper. The offset printing machines are capable of printing on recycled paper, although production volume is reduced because of the extra cleaning required by the dust given off by recycled paper. Recycled paper is currently not used more extensively because of its high cost. Recycled paper costs between 60 and 100 per cent more than the paper made from virgin pulp. However, discussions about this matter are continuing at present between officers of all parliamentary and government departments.

INTERJECT.PARA: Senator Dunn also asked me about the disposal of waste paper. A waste collection system operates throughout Parliament House. All office waste, including bottles, paper and other materials collected from the building, is sold for recycling. Approximately 10 tonnes of waste is disposed of in this way each week. Under the current contract, the Joint House Department receives $40 a tonne for that waste.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. Why does the Government tax the cash awards which are made to workers who devise procedures designed to increase productivity and save money? Why, for example, does a Royal Australian Air Force flight sergeant face a massive tax bill on a $13,220 award for devising a repair procedure on a brake control valve on the F111 aircraft that will save millions of dollars? Will half of the $10,000 recently awarded by the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel to Dr Fred Earl for his development work on the Jindalee over the horizon radar also be returned to Mr Keating? Are not legal judgments and lottery prizes tax free? Are our national productivity and the maintenance of our defence effort regarded as of lesser national importance than lotteries?
—You once based your defence policy on a lottery.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Ray reminds me that the Liberal Party of Australia once used to base its defence policy on a lottery. That was at the time of the Vietnam war. It suited honourable senators opposite then.
—Peals of laughter.
—It was not intended to be a joke, Senator.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Newman interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —It is not at all sick, Senator; a lot of people remember it. I suspect that the answer to Senator Newman's question is that the two examples she referred to involve income and are taxed as income. Lottery prizes have never been taxed as income and are not considered income for the purpose of the tax Act and that has been true of every government in the history of Australia. I must say that, with regard to innovation, the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation, for example, is currently reaching some arrangement with scientists in respect of innovations and their remuneration, not based on the tax mechanism but based on the level of reward returned to them. That may be the solution to the problem of the Department of Defence; but, of course, the circumstances may be entirely different.

—I have a supplementary question, Mr President. Am I to understand from the Minister that he does not see the importance, nationally, of productivity awards by both private enterprise and government having a national benefit and, therefore, that action needs to be taken to remove any imposition of taxation that may already be accruing to the awards?

—The difficulty with that question, if I may say so with respect, is that any work done by anybody in this economy improves the productivity of the economy. If one were to single out particular people from others and say that they would get a particular benefit through the tax system, that would be a very bizarre example indeed.
—Why would you give them awards then?
—People get rewards for all sorts of things.
—Awards.
—Awards or rewards. Most awards are taxable, the honourable senator will find, because they are treated as income. These awards are clearly treated as income.

—I direct a question to the Minister representing the Treasurer. With many thousands of school leavers now entering full or part time employment, can the Minister indicate whether any delays are occurring within the Australian Taxation Office (ATO) in issuing tax file numbers? If so, will the Minister take the necessary steps to ensure that none of these new entrants to the work force will be financially disadvantaged by departmental delays in the processing of new tax file number applications?

—Senator Colston gave me some notice of this question. I am advised by the Treasurer's office that there are currently no delays in the processing of tax file numbers within the ATO. Employment declaration forms ask whether the employee currently has a tax file number. If the employee does not, the form asks whether an application for a tax file number has been submitted, and then there are details about how the system operates. If the employee indicated on an employee declaration form that an application had been lodged but, in fact, that was not the case, no extension would be enforced at the end of the initial 28-day period. In any event, the ATO seeks to issue tax file numbers within 28 days from the date of lodgment of an application.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Resources. Does the Minister agree that the burning of wood as a domestic fuel where reasonable alternative fuels are available, is a wasteful use of this resource but, more importantly, a major contributor to the production of greenhouse gases which are harmful to the environment? Does the Minister agree that it would be desirable-in order to protect the environment from greenhouse gases-that steps be taken to reduce the level of wood burnt for domestic purposes?

—I am asked to agree to a proposition advanced by Senator Puplick in this question. It depends entirely on the type of wood that is burnt. If the wood is waste wood and has no other use, then it is a reasonable proposition to consider it as a heating or cooking fuel for domestic burning. In terms of the level of greenhouse gas emissions, I cannot inform the chamber of any energy source comparison at the moment. Decisions on whether to choose wood or some other energy source may depend upon the availability of a particular energy source. It may not always be the case that, in remote or distant locations, oil, natural gas or other energy mixes are appropriate. With those observations, I do not think I can help further in answering this question.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Bearing in mind the Minister's caveat that it would be reasonable if the wood were waste wood and would otherwise not be effectively used, or that its use might relate to availability in remote locations, can the Minister then explain why he has recently awarded a grant of $65,000 to a project in the Australian Capital Territory for the establishment of a hardwood plantation to provide fuel wood for domestic consumption in the Australian Capital Territory?

—If Senator Puplick had asked me that question straight off I could have given him an answer to the question. By way of introducing my answer, if Senator Puplick imagines that this is some enlightened contribution to the debate on greenhouse gas emissions, I suggest that it is a trivialisation of a quite serious debate. The burning of wood per se is not regarded as a significant or major element giving rise to greenhouse gas emissions.
—Not even in the tropical forests?

—In reply to Senator Puplick's interjection, a lot of timber from tropical forests is used in the timber industry for other purposes. Tropical forest cutting per se is not necessarily a matter for fuel, although I concede that in subsistence economies or in low standing agrarian economies timber is regarded as a fuel. The reason for the grant is to test the viability of such a plantation resource, given the immediate demand for such a resource in this vicinity.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Chapman Sen H.G.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister representing the Prime Minister and Minister for Industrial Relations. In the course of shedding crocodile tears for the pilots during a rambling interview on Perth radio on Friday, the Prime Minister said:

TALK.START.PARA: —I accept what Senator Chapman has said. The pilots were still technically employees within the system on 20 August. But I do not think that that makes any difference. As Senator Chaney pointed out in his question on Friday, on 20 August the Prime Minister made some remarks in the course of a radio program which suggested that the pilots should stay within the system and that if they did not there would be consequences from that.
—That is not what he said.

—Well, he said there would be consequences, if I might use a former Prime Minister's expression. As to the second part of the question, I said on Friday that as far as I am concerned it is a matter of regret when a union leaves the system and lays itself open to these sorts of remedies.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories. I note with interest the Minister's comments during Question Time on 30 October to the effect that:

QUESTION.PARA: . . . the Government decided earlier this year that the Wesley Vale pulp mill could go ahead only under the guidelines set by the Commonwealth, which were more stringent than those agreed to by the Tasmanian government of the day . . .

I ask the Minister: Firstly, are the Commonwealth guidelines, which the Federal Government said on 15 March 1989 would be available within four to six weeks, yet to hand? ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government indicated some six months ago that a Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation team would be sent to Europe to evaluate developments in guidelines for pulp mills there, and that group duly went. We said that we would bring the guidelines down by November. The honourable senator will probably catch us out being a little bit late. —Has the Minister for Consumer Affairs seen the recently released Economic Planning Advisory Council (EPAC) report entitled Measuring poverty? What are the implications of the report for social and economic policy development into the 1990s?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have seen the report in my capacity as Minister representing the Minister for Social Security in this place. The paper, issued through EPAC, very clearly identifies trends in poverty. Policy prescriptions needed in the future are identified as well. To that extent the Government welcomes the paper and will obviously consider it very seriously.

ANSWER.PARA: In terms of identifying trends in poverty, the paper makes one very fundamental point, and does so quite well. That is, over the last 20 years the problems of poverty have become problems, essentially, of homelessness, long term unemployment, youth unemployment, marriage breakdown, and hardship as it relates to immigrants and refugees. The paper makes one very fundamental point in terms of policy directions; that is, as a result of government reforms over the last few years, particularly in the areas of family allowance supplements, rental assistance and pension indexation, the question of poverty is now less a problem of inadequate income but more a problem of issues related to alienation, exclusion from full participation in society. The conclusion of the report is also instructive. It states:

Income support measures alone are not sufficient to deal with the broader aspects of poverty that exist in the Australian community. A broader range of other social policies will also be necessary . . .

The pivotal point there is that the EPAC report recommends to Government that we need to approach the question of poverty with research in a much broader range of areas than purely income support. The Government has recognised the vital role of these social wage measures. I have made that point a number of times in this place, as has the Minister for Social Security in the House of Representatives. We have often spoken about the importance of social wage measures such as Medicare, superannuation, Austudy, family payments and programs such as Newstart and jobs, education and training (JET). In September this year the Prime Minister in his address to the Australian Council of Social Service stated:
It is possible to describe poverty in terms of dollars and cents, or the lack of them. And it is possible to attack it in terms of financial benchmarks, as we have done.
But the causes and the symptoms of poverty are far wider than pure economics.
Perhaps we need a broader assault, ACOSS can help-along with State and local governments who have major interests in many aspects of this problem.

The point picked up by the EPAC paper is one that the Prime Minister also stressed two months ago. The Government has long recognised the need for a broader attack. That recognition will underlie the development of social policy on this side of the Parliament. It is also instructive to note that, whereas we have adopted this particular broad approach, the policy that the Opposition represents is totally different and destructive to the interests of good policy formulation in this area; it is the exact opposite. The Opposition would deny universal access to health care; it would freeze the number of high education places; it would abolish the programs that help families, for instance living--

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I raise a point of order. The Minister is perambulating across a whole lot of political points which have very little to do with anything. I ask you to tell him to stop debating the question and to sit down and let us ask another question.
—Minister, it is a very long answer. I ask you to conclude as quickly as possible.

—I will, Mr President. I make the point that there is a very clear distinction between this side of the Parliament and the other side in this very fundamental area. It is one that Senator Chaney ignored in terms of targeting appropriate rigorous policies when he was the Minister in this area, and he ignored it just a few months ago in the development of his Foster's family plan.

ANSWER.PARA: I will conclude on this basic point: there is a very clear distinction between the Government and the Opposition. At a time when the Government is taking a broad approach in this area, the Opposition is putting up programs that will cut back the social wage structures that have been identified by a body such as EPAC. The Opposition will cut back programs such as Skillshare, Jobstart, Newstart and JET which would effectively be abolished. As I say, the EPAC report provides a fundamental basis for policy development in this area. The Government has been working in that direction. I suggest to Senator Chaney that after the election when he is developing policy, in opposition again, this may be a good starting point.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister for Justice: What progress has been made by the Special Investigation Unit in the location and charging of war criminals resident in Australia? If, as yet, no charges have been laid, can the Minister advise whether or not any extension of the limit as to time or cost for the office to remain in operation is proposed or whether that matter has been discussed?

—The question of the operations of the Special Investigation Unit has been covered during the various inquiries by the recent Estimates Committee hearing. The cost of the operations of that Investigation Unit has been set out extensively and has been subject to examination in those Estimate Committee hearings. I commend those particular Hansard records to Senator Archer. As to the question about the stage that has been reached by the Special Investigation Unit in regard to its investigation of those persons within Australia against whom allegations have been made that they were involved in war crimes, I am looking for the latest statistic to see whether I have any new material. I do not know that I have any new material in addition to the matters put before the Estimates Committee. I am afraid that I cannot help with any quantification of the stage reached by the Special Investigation Unit. As to whether charges are imminent, that is a matter properly for the Director of Public Prosecutions (DPP). Once again at the Estimates Committee hearings, the stage of the special relationship between the Unit and the DPP was clearly outlined. I do not think I have anything further to add.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. In view of the fact that I understand that the appointment runs out on 30 April, or some time fairly early next year, I would like to know whether any arrangement has been made for an extension of the time or a reappointment, or what is proposed when the current appointment expires.

—I understand that the appointment runs out on 30 April 1990. I do not believe that the Government has given any consideration as to whether an extension will be required. Quite clearly, that will depend on such decisions as are made between now and then between the Special Investigation Unit and the Director of Public Prosecutions. It will only be in the light of the stage reached, perhaps in early or mid-April, that would necessitate a further decision being made by the Government as to whether or not an extension is warranted.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —On Wednesday, 22 November, Senator Archer asked me a question without notice on matters regarding the National Companies and Securities Commission. The Attorney-General has provided me with a response to the question about Mr Bosch making public comments. The response is as follows: The Attorney-General is aware of the statements which have been made by Mr Bosch concerning the conduct of Mr Skase and his companies. He does not believe it appropriate to make any comment concerning Mr Bosch's statements as the National Companies and Securities Commission is apparently investigating certain actions taken by directors of the Qintex group of companies.

There seems to be a problem with the federal system and joint cooperation between the States and the Commonwealth.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 21 November Senator Harradine asked a question relating to comments allegedly made by Ms Sue Boyd, our former High Commissioner to Bangladesh, to a recent meeting of the Australian Institute of International Affairs (AIIA). I am now in a position to provide the following supplementary information: Ms Boyd described to the meeting the components of Australia's aid to Bangladesh. This includes co-financing of the third International Development Association (IDA) Bangladesh population and family health project. For the details of this program I refer Senator Harradine to the documentation provided to him during the Senate Estimates Committee meeting on 26 September. This project is reviewed regularly and no evidence of coercion has been identified.

ANSWER.PARA: During her talk Ms Boyd identified population pressures as being one of the most important questions facing the Government of Bangladesh at this time. She noted that the Bangladesh Government attached high priority to the question and that President Ershad had received the United Nations population award in 1987. Her discussions with the Bangladesh authorities included discussion of population questions and the necessity to accord them high priority in all aspects of government planning and programs.

In her talk she spoke about the excellent relations Australia enjoys with the Government and people of Bangladesh which derive in part from Australia's effective development assistance program with that country. The access this rapport provided was useful to Australia in a number of fields, including that of trade promotion, and it was in this sense that Ms Boyd told the AIIA that Australian aid could be seen as a form of a lever when suggesting change.

Senator Harradine also asked me whether a population program which included elements such as he described could be construed as involving coercion. He queried whether Australia would support such a program. Senator Harradine will appreciate that often there is a fine line between coercion and incentive. All these matters have to be looked at on a case by case basis having regard to all the circumstances of the particular case. Nonetheless, on the face of it, an approach such as he has described would, under the kind of guidance that I have sought to give to the Australian International Development Assistance Bureau, be judged as probably being coercive and would not be supported.

Finally, Senator Harradine will be aware that Bangladesh is among the poorest countries in the world and one of the most densely populated. The current population is estimated at 110 million and the officially admitted rate of birth is 2.4 per cent per annum. At that rate the population could be expected to have doubled within the next 30 years. To try to form a mental picture of what this means in concrete terms, it might be helpful to note that, were the population of the whole world to be placed in Australia, the population density would still be lower than that of Bangladesh at the moment-a country two-thirds the size of Victoria. The continuing growth in population outstrips Bangladesh's tremendous strides in increasing agricultural production. The Bangladesh Government has itself acknowledged that the population question is the most pressing one facing it and that it needs to devise a complex strategy to address it. The Australian Government will continue to be as supportive as it reasonably can to the Bangladesh Government in that regard.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALK.START.PARA: —During Question Time, Senator Bishop made reference to some work Reark Research Pty Ltd had done on commercials concerned with the Buy Australian-made campaign. For Senator Bishop's information, when Luscombe and Partners and John Singleton Advertising made their presentations to the ministerial committee they were both rejected and asked to do better. When they came back with their second versions the Singleton agency was selected and the Reark research work was never done on the work which the Singleton agency was actually selected on; it was done on the work that was rejected. I have been advised in the last few minutes that the Singleton agency received no other government work, bar the Buy Australian-made campaign, certainly during the last four years. On the basis of that advice I suggest to Senator Bishop that an agency as big, as popular, as successful and as profitable as that could more than reasonably have expected to get more than that.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —During Question Time I was asked a question by Senator Brownhill on imported Canadian pig meat and food additives. I am now in a position to answer the honourable senator's question. The use of mecadox in pig feed in Australia is banned because of its potential as a carcinogen, particularly for feed handlers. Canada has one of the world's most effective residue monitoring programs which is equivalent to current Australian standards. It is expected that Canada will satisfactorily control misuse of the chemical. The level of violation is currently at less than 0.04 per cent.

ANSWER.PARA: Recent work in the United States of America has shown that carcass residues with carcinogenesis are of less concern than the real concerns that exist for the handling of the chemical in a concentrated form by mill attendants. It is not presently intended to specifically test Canadian products on arrival for mecadox. There is an internationally agreed principle that no country bans product imports on the basis that the exporting country uses a chemical which it does not, which is the concept proposed. Rather, the issue is addressed by authorities via minimum residue level testings.

TALK.START.PARA: —During Question Time I was asked a question by Senator Jones relating to the Australian sugar industry. I have additional information for Senator Jones which relates to pricing. The current world sugar market is characterised by tight supplies and firm pricing at present. It is expected that prices will remain strong or even increase over the next two years. However, prices in the medium term are likely to decrease as producer countries respond to the higher prices. Australian raw sugar production in 1989-90 is expected to reach 3.9 million tonnes, up from last year's record 3.68 million tonnes. Further production increases are expected in the 1990-91 season as increased cane production from a recent 5 per cent increase in cane assignment becomes available for harvest.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newman Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave -I claim to have been misrepresented. It has been drawn to my attention that in the Seymour Telegraph of Tuesday, 7 November, the Federal member for McEwen, Mr Peter Cleeland, in referring to me, said:

SPEECH.PARA: At the most recent Federal Liberal Party Council meeting in Sydney, she called for a staggering $6 billion increase to accommodate the purchase of two aircraft carriers, landing craft for the Navy and a helicopter support ship.

Again, today, I find almost the identical words in a letter from Jenny Cary of Dickson in the Canberra Times Letters to the Editor column. It seems as if there is an orchestrated attempt to discredit me. I would be grateful of the opportunity to put on record the correct situation with regard to these allegations.

At the Federal Council meeting in Sydney in June I moved no motion on any subject at all.
