DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received a letter from Senator Stone proposing that a matter of public importance be submitted to the Senate for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The suffering inflicted on homebuyers, farmers and other small business by the very high interest rates resulting from the failure of the Hawke/Keating Government's economic policies.
I call upon those senators who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of senators required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Stone Sen J.O.

TALKER.NAME: Senator STONE
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —In discussing this matter of public importance it is particularly noteworthy that it is directed not merely at home buyers and the suffering inflicted upon them as a result of the interest rates resulting from this Government's economic policy but also at the suffering of farmers and other small business people as well. In saying that, I do not wish in any way to diminish the suffering of home owners or mortgagees who, after all, are paying 17 per cent on their mortgages and, in many cases, more than that on second mortgages. I want to point out that there are some other people as well in this community who are suffering and, in many cases, suffering even worse. For example, credit card users are now paying interest rates of anything between 22 and 25 per cent. Farmers and other small businessmen are paying interest rates of between 23 and 25 per cent. Even prime borrowers today in the business community, such as Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd, are having to pay 20.75 per cent for their money-if they are borrowing on bank bills they can get it for the remarkably cheap rate of about 18.2 per cent.

SPEECH.PARA: Up in Queensland where I come from we have had a rate of population growth for so many years which has been so fast that the problem for home owners is particularly acute. We have a lot of new settlers in the State, many of whom have had to obtain finance to establish themselves. From that point of view, the degree of suffering referred to in the motion is of particular relevance to Queensland. I am not saying that it is not relevant to other States, but it is certainly relevant to Queensland, which I represent. To underline my point about the rate of population growth, in 1988-89 Queensland had a net immigration rate-that is, after allowance for people leaving the State-of 45,300 persons. That is an enormous rate of net immigration to the State. The only other State to gain population from other States in any significant degree during that year was your own State, Madam Acting Deputy President, Western Australia, which gained 9,500. I think South Australia gained a few hundred and the rest of the States all lost population, principally, as I said, to Queensland. If I may interpose one mild political comment--

TALK.START.PARA: —Oh, I am surprised at you!

—I will not resist the temptation on this occasion. I have to say that conservative governments in Queensland over the past 30-odd years-both coalition governments and, for the last six years, National Party governments-must have been doing something right: they have all these people wanting to live there.

SPEECH.PARA: Having referred to the very fast rate of population growth and the equally fast rate of job growth-in fact, the fastest in the Commonwealth-which has been rising by almost 6 per cent over the last 12 months, I point out that Queensland is still a very rural State and it happens to have, proportionally speaking, more farmers than perhaps any other State. Because in Queensland business tends not to be big business, such as is found in Victoria and in New South Wales, small business is the predominant form of business organisation there. It is that category which is particularly suffering, as I said earlier, from these very high interest rates.

Again, we have a very high concentration of tourism in my State. There is an industry which is characterised principally-almost entirely, in fact-by small business. That industry is suffering not merely from the very high interest rates resulting from Mr Hawke's and Mr Keating's policies, but also from the grievous effects of the air pilots dispute-a direct result not merely of the somewhat questionable activities of the air pilots but particularly of the inflammatory approach to the whole matter by none other than the Prime Minister. So the matter of public importance before us today happens to bear particularly upon the affairs of my own State, although it has general application throughout the Commonwealth.

The terrible thing is that nobody in the Government seems to care. I have just mentioned the air pilots dispute. The Government is doing nothing about that. I will not say much about that because that is not the subject before us today, but it has been going on and on. I think we are now into the 102nd day-I may have missed a day; it may be the 103rd day-and the Prime Minister has not even lifted a finger to tell Australian Airlines to go away and negotiate, to sit down with the pilots.

I will come back to what we were talking about-interest rates. There was a crushing rebuff handed out to the Hawke-Keating Labor Government last Saturday in South Australia. After all, it was a State election, but there was a massive fall in the Labor Party vote, notwithstanding the fact, which I have to acknowledge, that Mr John Bannon is, if I am to believe the public opinion polls, the most popular Premier in Australia. It was a massive vote of loss of confidence, not so much, I suspect, in his Government, although there may be some of that as well, but certainly in the Hawke-Keating Labor Government and a massive vote against the Government's interest rate policy. It is agreed on all sides that interest rates became the central issue of the campaign. There is no question about that. In part, that is what this matter of public importance debate is directed to today.
The fact is that there is no end in sight. I quote from an article in today's Australian:

Interest rates would have to stay high well into next year to curb the continuing blow-out in the trade deficit, the property group Baillieu Knight Frank warned yesterday. The November issue of the group's economic and property investment indicators says it would be irresponsible for either of the main political parties to signal during next year's election campaign an immediate and large fall in interest rates.

We are not going to do anything irresponsible of that kind because we have said all along that there is no magic wand. When a government produces, after what will be seven years of this Government's policies, the kind of mess we have on our hands today there is no magic wand. This Government has put us in the situation where undoubtedly interest rates will stay high for some time. We have policies-and we have announced them in our Economic Action Plan-which will address the issues. But we are not saying that those policies will bring down interest rates with a rush in the next month or so after we are elected. We would be irresponsible to say so. It is only Messrs Hawke and Keating who may be tempted-we will wait and see-between now and the election to try to bring about an artificial fall in interest rates by orders to the Reserve Bank to do as I say, as Mr Keating would say, and indeed as he did say some time ago.

Let us be quite clear that, in addition to the very high and crippling interest rates and the burdens they are placing on home buyers and home mortgagees, we now have a situation which is the subject of a very interesting article by Mr Maximilian Walsh in today's Sydney Morning Herald. A quite separate but related problem is now appearing in this area. I want to quote at length from Mr Walsh's article because it spells out the consequences for small people in this country today of the Hawke-Keating economic policies. Mr Walsh heads his article, `Falling home prices spell the end for Hawke'. There is nothing novel about that suggestion. He comments on the sudden sprouting of `For Sale' signs all over those parts of Sydney where he happens to drive or jog around. He says:
In the last few weeks the signs have spread more quickly than a measles epidemic.
He goes on:
Those signs will be the tombstones of the Hawke Government.
It's a buyers' market in the world of real estate and those sales represent heartbreak stories.

For every person who has to sell, there are multiples who would like to escape the crushing burden of mortgage payments that are about to become even heavier as the market for part-time female labour continues to contract and as the unemployment ranks expand.

In other words, these are people who are presently managing to scrape by, financing their much increased mortgage payments because the wife has gone out to work, and who find that her job all of a sudden disappears. Perhaps, indeed, the chief breadwinner in the family finds that his job disappears. Mr Walsh goes on to say:
Those `For Sale' signs-more of them than I can ever remember-emphasise the emptiness of the present economic debate of whether we will have a `hard' or a `soft' landing.

Nobody really knows the answer to that proposition. The reason nobody knows is that we have never faced quite this set of economic circumstances. At no time since the end of World War II have we had to deal with a situation of a magnitude that involves the wholesale contraction of community wealth which is now underway in Sydney-and spreading throughout the country-in the form of fast falling house prices.
Mr Walsh continues:

In looking at the political potency of the Sydney housing bust, which is about to spread through the nation, it is important to note that Saturday's swing against Labor in South Australia occurred because of high interest rates but in a State where housing prices have not yet begun to fall.

Mr Walsh then comments that, as yet, housing prices have been holding up in places like Melbourne, Canberra and Brisbane but he says that soon they will join in the fall in house values. I mention Mr Walsh's article at some length because I believe that Mr Walsh is correct when he says that this is a new phenomenon, a phenomenon brought on by this Government's policy. I do not want to spend any further time drawing out the political implications of that because the Government can work them out as well as I can and no doubt is already doing so. Government members have read the front page of this morning's Sydney Morning Herald, no doubt. They should be under no illusion that that is what is happening and that it will continue to happen.

I might say that in the months to come we will hear a lot less about the benefits and the tax rorts to be had from negative gearing. One remembers all that stuff we heard about negative gearing, particularly from the Australian Democrats. Anyone who has engaged in negative gearing in recent times is suddenly finding that he has a tiger by the tail, because the property that he bought and negatively geared is now falling in value, not rising, and he is still picking up these heavily inflated interest rates that Mr Keating has imposed on him in the process. So, this involves a whole new ball game, and no-one should be under any illusions about it.

The fact is that now nobody seems to care. Perhaps that is a slight exaggeration; perhaps Mr Hawke and Mr Keating do care. They might care about the fact that interest rates are so high, if only for political reasons. However, the problem they have is that they cannot seem to do anything about the matter. Why is that so? What are the things that they might do about it if they did not have their hands tied in one way or another? For example, they might cut government spending. No, they are not prepared to do that. In the Opposition's Economic Action Plan, brought down just over a month ago, we nominated in great detail $2.7 billion worth of cuts in government spending programs. However the Government itself is not prepared to cut a dollar.

Can the Government lower taxes? No-at least not responsibly. Of course, it cannot lower taxes because it will not cut spending-unlike the Opposition, which did nominate $2.5 billion worth of tax cuts, including a $2 billion family tax package and a decision to abolish the capital gains tax, a decision which will have the greatest benefit for the 750,000 or 800,000 small business people in this country when it takes place. Can Mr Hawke and Mr Keating lower inflation? No, they cannot lower inflation because they are locked into the so-called accord with the trade union movement. That has produced a situation in which, in the 12 months to the September quarter this year, prices have risen by 8.3 per cent and in which we are expecting a consumer price index for the December quarter, which we will know towards the end of January, that will probably increase the figure; it certainly will not lower it, or will not lower it in any way appreciably. To make matters worse, there is now muted talk about another wage-tax deal between this Government and its failed friends in the trade union movement early next year.

Can the Government raise productivity? No, it cannot do that. It has run away from doing anything about the shambles on the waterfront. It has run away from doing anything about the shambles with our coastal shipping, with the cost that that imposes on every Australian. The fact is that it costs more to send a motor car direct from Sydney to Auckland than it does to send a motor car from Sydney to Tokyo and back to Auckland. The Government has done nothing, and is not prepared to do anything, about that.

I do not have time to go into detail but, as Senator Alston particularly tells us every second day in this place, in the telecommunications industry the Government is refusing to take on the Australian Telecommunications Employees Association. This is because Telecom Australia is run by its unions, not by the Government and not by the management. The Government is unwilling to take on the major job of privatisation of government business enterprises. Again, this is because the Public Service unions and the Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU) have told it not to. So, any possible micro-economic reforms are blocked off by the Government's associations with its trade union masters.

We now have the supreme irony of Mr Keating, freshly back from a fortnight's holiday abroad-the Government kept him out of the country until the South Australian election was over-telling us about how the Government might start talking about enterprise unions. What a hide! Enterprise unions from the Australian Labor Party? In my time I have seen some attempts to steal the Opposition's clothes, but that really does take the cake, particularly when we know that it is simply rhetoric. The Government will not be allowed to undertake a move towards enterprise unions because the ACTU will not let it. The great virtue of enterprise unions will be the death of ACTU power in this country. They have to be the end of that power. The ACTU cannot exercise power over a multifarious number of unions, and that indeed, is why its policy is to diminish the number of unions in order to strengthen its power. Enterprise unions work in directly the other way. To have the Treasurer talking as he did about this matter is hypocrisy with a capital H.

There is nothing very surprising about this; it is the normal thing for Labor governments. After all, Messrs Hawke and Keating have produced the highest and, indeed, the most prolonged interest rate regime on record. From 1972 to 1975 Mr Whitlam produced a shambles in this country from which we have never recovered. To this day we have not recovered from the smash to which Australia was subjected under Mr Whitlam. The Wran-Unsworth Government, which was first elected in 1976, was finally thrown out last year in the greatest landslide, in the end, against Labor in New South Wales since the mid-1930s when Jack Lang was defeated. That result showed the revulsion which the people of New South Wales finally felt for the Labor Government in that State.

The Cain Government has been in office in Victoria since 1982. There has been one financial scandal after another. There have been the Victorian Economic Development Corporation scandal and the WorkCare scandal. Despite some running repairs to WorkCare, the situation is that WorkCare today has $5 billion-worth of outstanding unfunded liabilities to its discredit. State Bank Victoria this year reported, for the first time in its long and previously quite illustrious history, a massive loss, with write-offs all over the place because of financing bits and pieces of the State Government's schemes. While Mr Cain was certainly re-elected last October, I can only say that it is a great pity for the people of Victoria that he was, and they are coming to see that.

The Burke-Dowding Government in Western Australia was elected at the same time as the Hawke-Keating Government. There has been one scandal after another: the Swan Building Society, the Teachers Credit Society, Burswood Casino, Rothwells Bank, the State Government Insurance Commission, the Government Employees Superannuation Board, Petrochemical Industries Co. Ltd-the list goes on and on. Now there is a terrific fight going on between the Commissioner of Police and his Deputy. I do not have time to go into all that. I simply want to say, Madam Acting Deputy President, as you would be very well aware, that we have had five Labor governments, Federal and State, and five disasters. Last Saturday, of course, the people of South Australia expressed their opinion of Mr Bannon's Labor Government, which I did not mention, by taking away from it 6 per cent of its previous vote.

An election campaign is now taking place in Queensland. There has never been a greater need in that State for unity on the conservative side to make sure that what has happened in the other States is not repeated in Queensland-a State whose finances have been extremely well managed, as recently acknowledged by Access Economics Pty Ltd, which has produced figuring for the net public sector funding requirements State by State that shows Queensland having outstandingly the best managed finances of any State in this country. That is not my biased-I suppose one could say-claim; that is the statement of Access Economics based on the Statistician's figures. I simply want to say that we have had enough of the suffering imposed by this Government.

SPEECH.PARA: Today the shadow Minister for Finance has the gall to put forward the matter of public importance that we are debating when he is a co-author of a plan, the so-called Economic Action Plan, which explicitly describes how high interest rates will be the chief economic weapon of a coalition government; hence no reference to it today. In other words, what smattering of economic strategy that can be discerned from the Opposition's Economic Action Plan is one that is definitely anti-family.

In contrast, this Government has consistently implemented pro-family policies. Under this Government 1.5 million new jobs have been created. Breadwinners again have an opportunity to provide for their families. The teenage unemployment rate has been more than halved, removing the stress on family life generated by children being forced onto the dole. The school retention rate has doubled from one-third to two-thirds, which has given children a better start in life and ended the time in which parents, out of concern, parked their children in educational institutions rather than let them face unemployment. Now they have a chance to remain in educational institutions to learn skills and gain qualifications to fit them for careers.

We have increased the family allowance and indexed it to the rate of inflation to protect its real value-a policy that I note is not endorsed by the Opposition. We have had the landmark family allowance supplement, which has lifted children from poverty. Since March 1983, 930,000 homes have been constructed in Australia, housing families at an average of 150,000 a year-50 per cent higher than in 1983. The home ownership rate in Australia has risen from 71.5 per cent in 1984 to 73.4 per cent in December last year. Those are all part of our record of achievement for families. Families, small businesses and farmers have all benefited from these advances. What could be more anti-small business than a confiscatory tax of 78c in the dollar?

In contrast with our record of support for families and small business, Senator Stone, the shadow spokesman on finance, continued with his knocking, carping and gloomy routine. Senator Stone has no intention of offering any economic strategy of real concern for families or small business. His policy is, as Ross Gittins, the economic correspondent in the Sydney Morning Herald, described it:
. . . a recipe for slow growth, weak investment, rising unemployment, falling real wages, high interest rates and an over-valued dollar'.

But the Australian people will not be so easily misled. They will recognise that the Opposition parties-more so under their present leadership-have no capability whatsoever to deal with Australia's external challenge and therefore to deal effectively with interest rates. The challenge must be seen in perspective. It does the Opposition no credit when it seeks selectively to quote statements about the external debt. More balanced commentary has come from such highly respected commentators as the former President of the Business Council of Australia, Sir Roderick Carnegie, and the former Governor of the Reserve Bank of Australia, Bob Johnston. They have in recent times made much more balanced commentary. Like the Government, these commentators recognise that Australia's external debt is an issue but they do not attempt to scaremonger in the irresponsible way that Senator Stone has in the past, although he did not do very much of it today.

What are the facts? Australia's gross external debt of $137 billion, after making allowance for our official reserve assets and lending abroad, represents a net debt of about $108 billion. This is equal to a debt ratio of about 32 per cent of gross domestic product (GDP), about 2 per cent less than the recent peak of September 1986. As at the end of 1987, which is the most recent comparison available, Australia's gross external debt as a proportion of GDP was almost exactly equal to the average of the countries of the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development and was lower than the rate in Belgium, Denmark, Finland, Greece, Ireland, New Zealand, Norway, Portugal and Sweden and about half that of Argentina and Mexico. While the Macquarie Bank speculates on an external debt ratio of 59 per cent of GDP by the year 2000, studies commissioned by the Economic Planning Advisory Council suggest that the debt ratio could stabilise at around 30 to 35 per cent of GDP by the mid-1990s.

Of our external debt burden, the Commonwealth is a net creditor via its roughly $18 billion of debt being more than offset by $21 billion of official reserve assets. Sixty-two per cent of Australia's net external debt is owed by the private sector. The Commonwealth Government has actively been repaying debt abroad to such an extent that the Commonwealth's foreign currency debt has fallen from $15 billion at the end of June 1987 to $9 billion at the end of June 1989. By the end of this financial year Commonwealth debt on issue will be equal to only 13 per cent of GDP-less than half of what it was four years ago. I see that I am running out of time and will not be able to complete my address but I am sure that Senator Maguire will make many of these economic points when he speaks in this debate on behalf of the Government.

I return to the basic and fundamental theme that the Senate is a House in which politics are played. To the extent that high interest rates were the election issue in the South Australian campaign, and the South Australian electorate is a reasonable reflection of the national electorate, it would seem that, while the electorate is fed up with the Hawke/Keating Government, electors are by no means certain that a Peacock-led Opposition has the answers either.

He pointed out in that article that the Opposition illustrated by its behaviour in the House of Representatives last week that it was hoping `to ride to victory on the back of high interest rates while proposing policies that, in all probability, could force interest rates even higher'. Perhaps that is the answer to Senator Cook's complaint-that Senator Stone really did not address the issue directly in his contribution. Not having been able to get a full transcript at this stage, I will paraphrase what Mr Peter Duncan, the Federal member for the seat of Makin in South Australia, said on the Australian Broadcasting Corporation's radio program AM this morning: `The Liberal Party has almost an identical policy in relation to monetary issues and, given the ideas of John Stone, would probably be keener on an even tougher monetary policy than we have got'. Or I could quote from the speech made by Senator Stone on Friday, although I do not need to because he has said it again in this chamber this afternoon. He said that the Government cannot let interest rates fall and that, were the Opposition to be swept into government, it would not let interest rates fall, but that there is no magic wand; indeed, it is a case of more of the same. To make the point I will again use Kenneth Davidson's remarks in this morning's Age:

Perhaps the voters in South Australia understand that the budgetary stance of the Peacock Opposition is the same as the budgetary stance of the Hawke/Keating Government, which means that they will both have to rely to the same degree on monetary policy and wages policy for restraint.

The Opposition in this place cannot take any comfort from the South Australian election. I will cite a few quick figures to demonstrate that. There was a feeble attempt by Senator Stone to take some comfort from the figures. Perhaps we will see why it was such a gentle attempt. The Liberals' vote in South Australia was down; the Democrats' vote was up. The vote was up in a few lower House single-member electorate seats. In the seat of Alexandria, a Liberal-held country seat, the vote was up by 15 per cent, which is unprecedented in our history in that State. It was up 18 per cent in the seat of Devonport, a Liberal-held city seat; 16 per cent in the seat of Heysen, a Liberal-held seat in the hills area of Adelaide; and, just to look at the other side of things, 15 per cent was achieved in several metropolitan Labor seats. We achieved double figures in a number of marginal Liberal-held seats. In the past the Democrats have not really expected that sort of result in marginal seats. In fact, the Liberals lost votes to the Democrats in several seats, among them Bragg, Chaffey and Custance. There were even in some Labor-held and Liberal-swinging seats--

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Acting Deputy President, I raise a point of order. I wonder whether you should call Senator Powell to order. I understood that the matter of public importance was in relation to interest rates as they affect small business, home buyers and so on and not the South Australian election results.
—There is no point of order.

—Thank you, Madam Acting Deputy President. I was illustrating the context of an election campaign in which Senator Parer's Party ran on the Federal issue of interest rates and Government economic policy. I have finished my statistics, so Senator Parer might feel some relief. Everything I was using to illustrate the situation has occurred because the Opposition does not have a leg to stand on. It cannot show-as it did not show in this debate or in the same debate generated by the same shadow finance spokesman on the appropriate occasion last Friday-that it can do any better or any different. We need to look at the Opposition's record. There has been enthusiastic support for: the Government's deregulation of the financial system; entry of foreign banks; floating of the dollar; and increased foreign borrowings and ownership, in spite of a National Party policy, certainly in Queensland, against this. This was illustrated by Senator Stone and his colleagues voting in this very place against a register of foreign ownership, which register was raised at the instigation of the Australian Democrats. At this point I indicate that there has been a desperate attempt by the Opposition to show that there is some difference between it and the Government, whose policies it is so critical of in this matter of public importance before us today, which difference has focused on the issue of wages policy. In his article this morning, Ken Davidson further stated:

SPEECH.PARA: Thus, credibility on interest rates boils down to credibility on wages policy.

Because of that widely acknowledged similarity in the monetary policy area, on which I have quoted a number of people this morning from both sides, that credibility has to be demonstrated through the Opposition's wages policy. It is not just monetary policy on which the Opposition and the Government have been the same. As I indicated in debate last Friday, they have become birds of a feather in a number of areas: charges for tertiary education, concentrated ownership of the media, and various other areas which the public is now seeing. This desperate attempt to focus on wages policy is about all that the Opposition can come up with.

If we look at that wages policy we see that there is a difference. The Australian Labor Party (ALP), in government, has based its wages policy on the accord. Maybe a comment on that might be appropriate at this point. I refer to an article in the Melbourne Age on 16 November by Ken Davidson in which he pointed out:

Wage restraint through the accord has been a key factor in the strong growth of employment and output in recent years. And it has been maintained despite the strong demand for labor since the end of 1988, which would have resulted in a wages explosion had it not been for the discipline applied through the accord.
The Business Council of Australia, together with the Opposition, wants to scrap the accord in favour of enterprise bargaining.

It is important to mention that employer organisations are divided on this issue. That is noted in this article. Among them is the Metal Trades Industry Association, whose head, Mr Bert Evans, in the Sir Richard Kirby Lecture at the Wollongong University, outlined some of those concerns when he said that the move was opposed by the MTIA because it would lead to inflationary wage settlements, as the biggest gains negotiated with one enterprise in the industry would be imposed on the rest through comparative wage justice. He pointed out that the spread of inflationary wage settlements would be facilitated in his industry through factory-by-factory negotiations conducted by national, not enterprise, unions. Ken Davidson suggests that, if Mr Evans is correct in his assessment of the wages policies advocated by the Business Council and the Opposition, the inevitable result would be a precipitation of a devaluation of the Australian dollar and a recession.

As I said in a debate similar to this debate on Friday, that brings us to what I am beginning to term the Sir Roderick Carnegie solution. Sir Roderick has told us that we can get out of this economic mess in the same way we did in the 1890s and the 1930s. If we reflect on how that occurred, we do see depression. Perhaps we can get away with recession this time-who knows? It is not a very attractive picture if the Opposition does push that one difference that it can show between it and the Government.

Clearly there is a need for an alternative. The South Australian voters have demonstrated that many in the community agree with the Australian Democrats when we say that there is a need for an alternative. We have said that we provide an alternative. We have said that an incremental approach in industrial relations, without ideological blinkers towards government intervention and regulation, is important on the basis of social or economic need. Indeed, we have said that often. I will not use our own words this morning. I will refer, again, to Kenneth Davidson's article in the Age this morning. He stated:

The Democrats, for instance, have just completed an overhaul of their tax policies that could form a lesson in rationality for both the major parties, whose relentless seeking after an electoral majority apparently means they are incapable of developing tax policies that serve both the interests of national efficiency and individual equity.

He goes on to say that, given that this has developed a policy platform built around the integration of social justice and environmental issues into economic decision making, this has been noticed in the community. This is the sort of policy direction which will be needed. It is the only sort of policy direction which can save us from, if you like, the Carnegie solution.

In this morning's newspapers we have seen reports of the latest Economic Planning Advisory Council report which has warned that poverty will get worse, that poverty is in danger of being entrenched in our community, that in the 1990s poverty will be worse than in the 1960s. If for no other reason, I think that should motivate us towards and should make us realise the need for the situation reported in an article in this morning's Age newspaper which said:
A broader range of other social policies will also be necessary, as well as a commitment to maintain them over the realistic period of time, for the problem of poverty to be tackled.

It is that very integrated approach in policy making, which has been referred to by Davidson, which the community in South Australia has acknowledged is necessary and which it had searched for in the Labor Government and in the coalition Opposition, but all in vain. I do not think it is sufficient for a virtual identical motion to be brought before this chamber today in preparation for yet another State election to get either the Opposition or the Government away from acknowledging what has happened in South Australia. It is important to look at what has happened-apart from the figures which upset Senator Parer so much-and perhaps at some of the commentary in conclusion. The Australian Labor Party National Secretary has responded, as reported in today's Australian newspaper, with this statement:

`We understand that there's a lot of hurt, a lot of resentment out there because of the squeeze on the hip-pocket nerve, because of interest rates and other factors like that,' he said on Channel Nine's Sunday program.

I think that that represents a breakthrough on behalf of the people of Australia. Further, Mr Bannon, the narrowly successful Premier, has been reported as saying that the result in South Australia is saying something about the two-party political system and something that the two major parties must have some regard to. In an article in this morning's Sun News-Pictorial Niki Savva said:
The vote showed there is plenty of room for another major force in Australian politics. At the moment it's the Democrats . . .
That is the message: alternative economic policies are needed, not more of Tweedledum and Tweedle-even-dumber.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Parer Sen W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support the matter of public importance raised by my coalition colleague Senator Stone, which states:

SPEECH.PARA: The suffering inflicted on homebuyers, farmers and other small business by the very high interest rates resulting from the failure of the Hawke/Keating Government's economic policies.

This Hawke-Keating Government, by its macro-economic policies over a lot of years and its failure to act on micro-economic reform, has brought the Australian economy precariously close to a Third World country status. What a dismal record after seven years. Yet over the years we have heard the Treasurer (Mr Keating) say that running the economy was fun. It might be fun for him, but it has not been fun for Australians. He said that it was only a matter of pulling levers. Year in and year out the Treasurer has made forecasts about the hard times being over and the economy improving, and each year he has been very wrong.

All sorts of excuses have been given. One in particular that comes to mind is the unexpected downturn in our terms of trade. Of course there was the classic remark, that home buyers today will only too well remember, that there are too many people in Australia who want a home with a backyard and a Hills hoist. Everyone will remember that great statement. We have heard that the reason for the frightening growth in our current account deficit has been on the one hand a surge in investment spending in capital goods which will pay dividends in the long run. I would have thought that seven years was long enough and most Australians today would say that it was far too long. On the other hand it is claimed by the Government that the cause of the growing current account deficit is that ordinary Australians are spending too much on consumption goods; that is, buying imported goods that we are unable to make in Australia mainly because of an antiquated centralised industrial relations system which absolutely guarantees a comparative lack of productivity and interest rates at a level which precludes new investment and destroys what is already there.

The Government cannot have it both ways as to the reason for the level of imports. But the response from the Government is to tighten monetary policy-in other words, to treat the symptoms and not the disease that it has had seven years in which to cure. That is the problem. That is what Senator Stone referred to. It is a policy that clearly has not worked. At this stage we are enjoying over a relatively long period our best terms of trade in a decade. In both price and volume terms our exports over the past year in the main have been the best we have had for 10 years. The single lever theory has been: tighten monetary policy, interest rates rise, the exchange rate is propped up, demand for consumption goods will be reduced and imports will be reduced.

What has the Government achieved with its policies? Our current account deficit for the four months from July to October now stands at $8.2 billion. It is estimated that our foreign debt is increasing at the rate of our total annual sugar exports every 20 days. Net foreign debt has risen in seven years of hard labour from about $33 billion to about $110 billion. Home interest rates have risen in the last seven years from 13.5 per cent to 17 per cent notwithstanding promises from the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) at the time of the Western Australian election in February this year that interest rates would be down by Christmas. In fact, to check the veracity of this Government and this Prime Minister I thought I would just go back over the period that this Government has been in power and pick out a few remarks, almost on a yearly basis. In 1984 on a John Laws radio program, the Prime Minister said:
. . . because inflation is coming down and inflationary expectations are down, interest rates will come down too.
In 1985 on the PM program the Treasurer, Mr Keating, said:
I still stand by the remark I made in the election campaign that I think there is an interest rate step fall ahead for Australia and its interest rate structure generally to 1985.
In 1986 the Prime Minister said:

It is so obvious that it is hardly necessary to say it, but everyone in this country would like to see lower interest rates. Of course, what we are about is to secure a situation in which we will be able to enjoy permanently lower interest rates.
In 1987 in the House of Representatives the Prime Minister said:
We look to 1987 with a cautious optimism about the economy including a fall in interest rates in 1987.
On 28 January 1989, when campaigning in Perth before the Western Australian election, the Prime Minister said:

Now when those things occur (adjustments brought about by economic policy), as I believe they will, it's those sorts of circumstances that will produce the environment within which interest rates can fall.
On the same day the Melbourne Age reported that, when asked in Perth whether interest rates would fall this year, the Prime Minister said:
They'll go down this year.
The article continues:
Yesterday he was asked whether there was a chance rates might rise before they fell. He said, `No, I don't believe so.'

These interest rates are driving ordinary, average Australians to desperation. They are pressing families to cut back on essentials and, in many cases, driving them out of their homes. Charities such as the St Vincent de Paul Society and the Salvation Army are reporting record requests from families on or below average weekly earnings just for food and clothing. Of greater long term significance is the inability of young married couples even to contemplate purchasing their own homes. This has occurred over a period of seven years under this Government, and all honourable senators opposite do is get up every now and then and say that they care. All this Government cares about is big government, big unions and a couple of rich mates. This Government has completely lost touch with the aspirations of average Australians.

The Real Estate Institute of Australia found that more than 30 per cent of the average family income in Queensland is now needed to meet home loan repayments. That is well above the established affordability benchmark of 25 per cent of average family income. Queensland families are now paying, on average, $185 more for their mortgages than they were just 12 months ago. The blame for this dreadful situation lies squarely with this Hawke Labor Government and its failed economic policies. It has deliberately pursued a policy of high interest rates in an attempt to dampen spending, as I indicated earlier.

Interestingly enough, the Queensland Labor Leader, Mr Wayne Goss, must also share the blame because he continues to support the high interest rate policies of his Federal comrades despite the obvious suffering they are causing home buyers. In fact, Mr Goss said in a television interview some two or three months ago that high interest rates were not an important issue in Queensland. What an incredible statement!

TALK.START.PARA: —Did he really say that?

—He actually said it on television. In fact, I notice that, even after the South Australian election, the Labor pollster is saying that he thought that, in the recent election campaign in South Australia, interest rates were vastly exaggerated as an issue. I wonder what people over there thought the issue was.

SPEECH.PARA: Over the past 12 months overdraft rates for borrowings of less than $100,000 have risen to over 22 per cent. I submit that few, if any, legitimate businesses in the competitive areas of our economy can cope with these sorts of interest rates and an inflated exchange rate. It is impossible for anyone in an industry competing with imports when equivalent rates overseas are around 6 per cent for Japan, 8 per cent for Germany and 10 per cent for the United States of America. This Government has consistently delivered to Australians the highest interest rates in our history and in the industrial world. What a shameful record! Is that all this Government has to show after seven years in office? As I indicated earlier, year in and year out, for seven years, members of this Government have stood up and said, `Things will get better next year'. Of course, we should add to that the month-in, month-out increases in the cost of living of families as reflected in the consumer price index-a figure locked in at around 8 per cent which is 50 per cent higher than the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development average. So much for the accord.

In Queensland the comrades of the Federal Labor Government do not want to talk about these issues. They are doing everything in their power to distance themselves from their Federal colleagues. The Queensland Labor Leader, Mr Goss, is even pretending that he is not part of the Labor Party. It is significant that the only visit made to Queensland in the State election campaign was to Mount Isa where even the local Trades and Labour Council gave him the thumbs down.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Prime Minister, you mean?

—The Prime Minister was given the thumbs down by the local Trades and Labour Council. The problem of tight monetary policy and record interest rates affects directly and indirectly all Queenslanders and all Australians, whether they be farmers, small business people, or home buyers. Add, of course, the problems of Mount Isa. What incredible judgment! We have the same problems everywhere in Australia but the airlines are the lifeline of Mount Isa. Of course, that has added to sending business people broke in the north, the far north, Brisbane and the Gold Coast.
—The Prime Minister travelled in his executive jet, I suppose?

—Yes, and he did not stay for very long. They almost ran him out of town. It shows incredible judgment on the part of Mr Goss in even taking him there. I understand that 150 conventions have been cancelled just on the Gold Coast. It is a loss not just to the major hotels but, more importantly, to the many dozens of little service industries. These lost conventions cannot be recovered; they have gone somewhere else. The many small businesses that serve these conventions, from food suppliers, hire companies and so on, cannot survive this dual onslaught of business lost and debt servicing.

SPEECH.PARA: The Leader of the Labor Party in Queensland, Mr Goss, has warned candidates to brace themselves for an avalanche of what he calls `mud-slinging'. Senator Cook was very quick to talk about corruption but he did not mention the corruption brought upon every Australian and every Queenslander by the failed economic policies of this Government. Mr Goss has said that, if any mention is made in this State election campaign of Labor's high interest rates, which affect every mortgagee and every business, and if any mention is made of entrenched trade union power, that is mud-slinging. Let me quote, for example, from what the Prime Minister said just this year in addressing the Australian Workers Union:
Trade unionists once sought political representation through the political wing of the labour movement; now they are vital partners with the Labor Party in government.

He was telling the people of Queensland that, if the Labor Party should happen to get into power up there, every committee and every qango would have trade union representation. There would be no attempt to break down the corruption on the waterfront which has almost brought this country to its knees. The waterfront, which affects this country's potential to export, in turn could correct our current account deficit. It has been estimated that that corruption is costing this country over $1 billion a year directly. I think it is a matter of getting this corruption into some sort of perspective. If the Labor Leader in Queensland, Mr Goss, says that, if we raise that matter, it is mud-slinging, so it is. He has said that it is mud-slinging to refer to the continuing price increases in the supermarkets and the cumulative effects of Labor's policies in reducing the standard of living of every Queenslander. As occurred at the South Australian election last Saturday, at the Queensland election next Saturday Queenslanders have the opportunity to give Labor a message: `After seven years we have hurt enough, we have had enough and Labor cannot be trusted'.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Maguire Sen G.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —This afternoon we are debating a matter of public importance which has been brought forward by Senator Stone on behalf of the National Party of Australia. Given that the two speakers on the other side of the chamber are both from Queensland I suppose we have to assume that this matter of public importance has been brought forward in the context of the election to be held in Queensland next Saturday.

SPEECH.PARA: We in the Labor Government know that families are concerned about interest rates, the subject of this matter of public importance today. On a number of occasions the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) has acknowledged his concern about interest rates. He has made it clear time and again that we in the Federal Government are not artificially holding interest rates high for the sake of high interest rates.

TALK.START.PARA: —I acknowledged that. I said that you have no other response in terms of policy.

—That may be the case, but the point is that we are certainly not holding interest rates at high levels for the sake of having high interest rates. We have said repeatedly that interest rates will be able to come down as soon as is economically possible in Australia and not before that time. We are not going for short term political gains and we are not going for a quick economic fix which is the predilection of a number of conservative members of parliament in this country. We saw that last week in my own State of South Australia, where the Liberals in their campaign for the State election promised virtually everything to the voters of South Australia. They promised the earth-anything to get a vote-and look at the results: they came in second on Saturday night.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Stone and Senator Powell made some comments about the links between interest rates and the results in South Australia. I have looked at the results. I do not profess to have all the details at this stage, but I found it very hard to find a link between the mortgage belt suburbs, so to speak, and the swing against the Government. For example, the State electorate of Newland, which is certainly part of a region of South Australia which has the highest rate of home purchasing anywhere in Australia, had the lowest swing against the Government on Saturday night. I was commentating on one of the television networks and I certainly saw many of the figures that were coming in. It seemed to be the case that the seat of Newland in the Tea Tree Gully region had a very low swing. I understand that the seat of Bright, which is another part of the metropolitan area, the southern part, which is also a mortgage-belt electorate, had a relatively low swing.

So, I would like to do some further research on the figures. At this stage I must say that Mr Rod Cameron may well be right. If he made the remarks that were attributed to him a moment ago he may well be right-that the State election in South Australia was determined by a range of issues and perhaps interest rates was not the dominant feature. I would like to look at that.

We have high interest rates in this country because we have a balance of payments current account deficit. Our overseas trading deficit, including services, is in a situation where we expend more overseas than people overseas expend in Australia. We are trying to encourage capital to come to Australia to finance that deficit. The deficit is occurring because Australia's economy has been growing too fast. It is as simple as that. We have had very high rates of economic growth in Australia. The consequence of economic growth is the importation of large volumes of overseas goods. That is the phenomenon that has been occurring in Australia. For example, last financial year the total amount of production in Australia, the gross national product, rose by 3.3 per cent. That is a reality; it is on the record: there was a 3.3 per cent growth in total production in Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —What happened to demand? That is what is important.

—Total expenditure in Australia-I think Senator Stone is talking about that-gross expenditure, grew by 7.7 per cent. We had that automatic spillover, imports surge if you like, on the products brought in from other countries. Of course, a high growth situation is the reverse of the situation faced by the Liberals when they were in government. They have not ruled in a situation of high economic growth for many years. They are uncomfortable with it. They are more comfortable with doom and gloom, recession and driving Australia's economy into the floor. That is what happened in the early 1980s.

SPEECH.PARA: One of the problems we have in Australia is that an investment surge is occurring. I did not make the figures up, and I am sure that the Treasurer (Mr Keating) did not make them up. The fact is that in the last financial year there was a 16 per cent growth in business investment in Australia. An astounding investment boom is occurring in this country to make Australia more productive. It is the biggest investment boom in this country's history, certainly in the twentieth century.

The matter of public importance that Senator Stone has raised in the context of the Queensland election refers to farmers and other small businesses, as well as homebuyers. If there is a 16 per cent growth in investment across the Australian economy, farmers and small businesses must be investing. It is such a phenomenally high aggregate figure for investment expansion in this country that all sectors must be sharing in it. It must be very difficult for anybody to identify a sector which is not experiencing the 16 per cent growth factor. We have to be very mindful of those factors when looking at this matter of public importance.

What are the alternatives to high interest rates? High interest rates are not existing in a vacuum; they are there for an economic reason. What are the alternatives? One of them would be to let the value of the Australian dollar go down compared with overseas currencies. The short impact of that would be that the prices of imported goods would rise dramatically. Competitors of those imported products would raise their prices and we would find price rises occurring across the board. We would see the consumer price index pushed upwards as import prices rise and we would simply have extra inflation in Australia.

One of the alternatives to the high interest rates we have at the moment would be a higher level of inflation and higher price rises. Do the Liberals want that as an alternative? We have deafening silence from those on the other side of the chamber about what they see as an alternative to high interest rates. The danger is that if we did not have high interest rates, if the capital was not coming into Australia to finance the balance of payments deficit, there would be an inflationary surge in the Australian economy. The Liberals have a very poor record on inflation. When they left office in 1983 we had double-digit inflation in Australia. Not only did we have very high and rising unemployment but also we had high inflation. The consumer price index under the Liberals in their last 12 months in government rose by 11 1/2 per cent. Today they are being very silent about what they see as the alternatives to high interest rates.

The reality is that the Liberal Party in government up to 1983 did as much to reduce interest rates as Harold Lasseter did for Australian gold production. That is the fact, that is the reality. It cannot deliver on interest rates. It is incapable of delivering on interest rates. A key determinant of interest rates is the inflation rate, the deflator for gross domestic product or, more popularly, the consumer price index. Those indexes affect interest rates to some extent. Lenders build into their lending rates their estimate of the inflation rate to ensure that they get a return on their funds in real terms.

It is interesting to compare inflation rates. I just mentioned the rate of inflation under the Liberals a moment ago. It was 11 1/2 per cent in their last 12 months of office. Under Labor that inflation rate has been wound back dramatically. At present we have an 8.3 per cent rate of growth in the consumer price index. We do not have a 9 per cent growth rate in inflation, we certainly do not have a 10 per cent rate of growth in inflation, and we certainly do not have the whopping 11 1/2 per cent surge in consumer prices which occurred when the Liberals were in power. On that one particular determinant of interest rates we have wound back, and I am sure that the management of the economy under Labor will achieve further reductions in, the rate of inflation.

We should also look at aspects of government spending. The Liberals also claim that they would do something to wind back interest rates by cutting government spending. I presume that the argument is the old crowding out effect, which has become a bit discredited in economics. The idea is that if a government goes out and borrows money it somehow forces up interest rates for other borrowers. That seems to be the type of logic being used by the Opposition. It says that it would cut government spending and therefore reduce that pressure on lending rates in the community.

The reality is that the Hawke Labor Government has already cut government spending dramatically. We have seen the share of gross domestic product taken by government spending reduced dramatically time and time again under this Hawke Labor Government. For example, when the Liberals left office in 1983 government spending accounted for 28.9 per cent of Australia's gross domestic product. That is a fairly high figure. The figure this financial year under the Hawke Labor Government is not 27 per cent or 25 per cent. In fact, it is estimated to come in at 23.7 per cent of gross domestic product. If there is some validity in that argument about crowding out, government borrowings somehow forcing up interest rates for other borrowers, then certainly the Labor Government has done more than could ever be expected of it in winding back in that particular area.

It is also important to realise that the Liberal Party in its rhetoric about interest rates overstates interest rates in making comparisons with the past. In the past people could not just roll into a bank and say, `I need X thousand dollars to purchase a family home'. When people did that in years gone by they got only part of the loan at the low interest rate and were then sent around to the banks' hire purchase company or finance company or were told to get a personal loan. In other words, they had to have a second mortgage at a much higher interest rate. So the average rate of interest on borrowed funds in the past was much higher than those opposite would have us believe. We have to look at the effective rate on the first and second mortgage. I certainly had to take out a very expensive second mortgage to purchase my first family home. I was simply told to go to the bank's other arm and get a personal loan at a much higher interest rate. I am sure that many Australians did that in the past, but they no longer have to do that when purchasing a home.

Despite the high interest rates this year, more dwellings are being commenced under the Labor Government than were ever commenced under the Liberals in office. Let us get to the real bricks and mortar activity; let us look at the real housing commencements in Australia. When the Liberals were in power there were 105,000 housing starts in its last year of office. Under Labor last financial year the figure was in the vicinity of 160,000. Under the Labor Government there has been at least a 50 per cent rise in the number of annual housing starts in this country.

I noticed that previous speakers on this matter talked about Queensland. It is very instructive to look at the housing starts in Queensland when the Liberals were in power in Canberra and compare them to those of the present day. Under the Hawke Labor Government in the last financial year there were 40,400 housing starts in Queensland, but in the last year that the Liberals occupied the treasury bench in Canberra there were not 40,000 and there certainly were not 30,000: all that could be managed under the Federal coalition Government in that period was 24,000 housing starts. In other words, 15,800 fewer dwellings were commenced in Queensland under a Federal coalition government than there were under the Hawke Labor Government in the last financial year.

One factor that has boosted housing starts under the Labor Government is the first home owners scheme. It was introduced by Mr Hawke in his 1983 policy speech. It is a targeted scheme and, very importantly, it is income tested: it is not available to the wealthy. Previous Liberal Party schemes were certainly available to people on very high incomes. Lower and middle income people are helped under this scheme to purchase their first home. They get assistance of up to $5,000 over five years to purchase their first home. Nationally, since that scheme started under Labor, $1,400m-I did not say $400m-has been spent on the first home owners scheme and 328,000 Australian families have been assisted. I would like to put on record this afternoon that in Queensland, which, as I pointed out, appears to be the subject of this matter, under the Hawke Labor Government 62,500 families have been assisted under the first home owners scheme, with total approved expenditure in that State amounting to a massive $244m. That is a very large level of spending under the first home owners scheme in Queensland.

One thing that has not been talked about here today is the cost of building land. The Liberals would have us believe some fiction that the only thing that determines how many houses are built in Australia is the level of interest rates. That is not true. I remember serving on a working party in the South Australian Government over a couple of years, and it was quite clear then that the cost of building allotments was a major determinant of home ownership. DEBATE.TITLE: DEPARTMENT OF COMMUNITY SERVICES AND HEALTH

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

I commence by welcoming a report as detailed and as comprehensive as this one. In particular, I pay tribute to those responsible for putting it together in a way which is readily understandable and for providing in it an index of some 11 pages which allows one to seek out within two very complicated departments a quick reference to issues which are of concern. I hope that will become an increasing trend in authority and departmental reports.

I want to mention only one or two things arising from this annual report. The first is the interesting divergence one finds if one looks at the statistical area of this report, particularly at tables 17 and 18, which deal with notifiable diseases. They give details of the diseases notified according to the necessary statutory requirements and the communicable diseases intelligence information obtained by virus laboratory reports received in the same period. What is interesting is the fact that the two do not entirely coincide. The reason they do not coincide is that in a large number of these areas people in the medical profession do not notify, for various reasons, the extent of the disease which they are treating. When one looks at this within the context of the policy on the acquired immune deficiency syndrome (AIDS), one sees that the reliance which has often been placed on legislative prescriptions that certain things must be notified is simply demonstrated as essentially a very weak tool to be used as far as monitoring the progress of the disease is concerned. Those who put reliance primarily upon legislative authority in these areas will find that these figures provide further evidence that their best endeavours will be confounded.

The second thing I want to say about the communicable diseases intelligence data is that it shows the increase in the incidence of one particular disease over a period of years. That disease is Ross River fever, which has now declined from a peak of 1,623 in 1984 to a figure of 679 in 1988. I draw attention to the fact that this is one of the diseases which are affected very much by environmental conditions. If the predictions of changes in the Australian climate as a result of the greenhouse effect are borne out, this is one of those environmental-related diseases in which we are likely to see an increase in incidence-a disease that is mosquito borne and transmitted.

I want to refer to only two other matters in the very brief time we have available. The first is to draw attention to the details this report gives of the Government's continuing program in the fight against AIDS. I congratulate the Government, which has received bipartisan support on this matter, for the expenditure and the programs which have been undertaken. I still do not believe that the popular media, those in television and those responsible for controlling advertising, are pulling their weight in assisting the Government. I take this opportunity to pay tribute to Mr Warren Talbot, who has recently retired as the Executive Director of the Australian Federation of AIDS Organisations to take up a position with the Government of Tasmania where he will be working on the continuing fight against this disease.

I indicate just how unfortunate the lack of information provided in relation to aspects of the pharmaceutical benefits scheme is within this annual report and in particular the false impression which is given that the database study which has been the object of so much attention in this chamber was, in fact, an adequate study and was adequately dealt with. Those criticisms, nevertheless, having been made, I believe this is a useful and significant report. It is well prepared and presented. I hope that it will become something of a model for other annual reports in terms of complexity of major departments.
