PROCTEXT.PARA: The Clerk-A return to order relating to details of all provisions of Acts which come into effect on proclamation and which have not been proclaimed, together with a statement of reasons for their non-proclamation and a timetable for their operation, is tabled pursuant to order of the Senate of 29 November 1988.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

The document that has been circulated is the third in a series resulting from a successful motion that I moved in the Senate on 29 November last year. In the previous documents 74 pieces of legislation were referred to. This time there are 75. So we do not seem to be progressing a great deal, although when one does a more detailed analysis one finds that there has been progress and that some of the additions are unavoidable. I refer to page 17 of the document. Some of the Acts had been overlooked previously. For example, the Department of Primary Industries and Energy suddenly discovered that there were a number of Acts that it did not know about that had been passed by the Parliament but that were unproclaimed. They are, for example: the Minerals (Submerged Lands) (Exploration Permit Fees) Act, the Minerals (Submerged Lands) (Production Licence Fees) Act, the Minerals (Submerged Lands) (Works Authority Fees) Act, the Minerals (Submerged Lands) (Registration Fees) Act and the Minerals (Submerged Lands) (Royalty) Act. If the Department did not know it had the Acts in its possession I do not suppose anybody else in the community would realise that the Parliament has spent a great deal of time passing Acts which even the Department did not know existed. A fascinating aspect should be brought to the Senate's attention. The explanation which is required says this:

These Acts cannot be proclaimed until complementary legislation has been passed by the States and the Northern Territory so that a uniform offshore minerals regime may be established in accordance with the offshore constitutional settlement.
Let us remember that this is a 1981 Act. This is the glacial exercise we sometimes find. The explanation continues:
Development of this legislation was suspended pending a review of the offshore constitutional settlement, which was instituted following the change of government in 1983.
That, by the way, was the incoming Labor Government. We are talking about almost seven years ago, when the Labor Government was first elected. The explanation goes on:
Since then the Commonwealth, States and the Northern Territory have decided on major amendments that need to be made to the Minerals (Submerged Lands) Act 1981.
That must have been a hoot of a committee to sit on. The explanation continues:
Completion of the drafting of these amendments has been delayed by higher priority bills.
So presumably they got around to deciding on something but it had to be put aside because priority was given elsewhere. It goes on:
Subject to the priorities of the Government's legislation program, it is envisaged that amendments of the Act will be introduced during the 1990 autumn sittings of the Parliament.

Presumably by the incoming Liberal government, I suppose Senator Puplick will probably want to add. It would be somewhat ironic if the whole seven years of the Labor Government were taken up in discussion. We might even start back at the beginning. I will be able to have a go at Senator Puplick on this next year when nothing has been done. The explanation continues:
Following passage of these amendments-
that is, these amendments which have not yet been introduced but which might be introduced some time next year-
the States and the Northern Territory would then be able to finalise their legislation.

Let us remember that we got into this because it says that the Act cannot be proclaimed until complementary legislation has been passed. So it is a nice little chicken and egg exercise and I am not sure where we come out.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is a little infelicitous.
—The explanation says:

SPEECH.PARA: These Acts cannot be proclaimed until complementary legislation has been passed by the States and the Northern Territory . . .

However, they cannot get their act in order until we pass our amendments. So presumably when we get these done, the States and the Northern Territory will pass theirs, the legislation will come back and we might be able to do something about it.

I wish all of this had been decided on in 1981-it would have made things a darned sight easier-instead of the Parliament spending a good deal of its time pushing something around that nobody had any intention, presumably, of doing something about for another eight or nine years. Indeed, a great deal of the legislation that will go through in the next four weeks could be dealt with in the same fashion.

The Health Legislation Amendment Act, under community services and health, was on the previous list. It is on this list also. But progress has been made, let us not fear. Previously with regard to these matters we did not have this agreement. I read from the last explanation we had:
A decision on whether to amend, repeal or retain the provision is expected to be made shortly.

I am sure that honourable senators will be agog to know that this decision has been made shortly and that now we have a new reason as to why nothing is going to happen, which is that there is now agreement at the Commonwealth level that an amendment is required to the definition of `personnel supervisor' in section 3aa. The nature of the amendment is yet to be settled and agreed on by the State health Ministers preparatory to the drafting of the amendment and a subsequent proclamation of the amended section. Presumably we will see that another day. It only goes back to 1986, so I suppose that we should not be too upset about it.
Under employment, education and training we have a new item. It says in regard to the Student Assistance Amendment Act:

These sections will automatically commence on 1 January 1990 under subsection 2 (3) of the Act, unless they are proclaimed sooner. It is unlikely that these sections will be proclaimed sooner because the associated regulations are still being drafted.

I wish to draw attention to that because there is now a drafting instruction from the Government which requires that there be that type of provision in the Act. The reason for my drawing this to the attention of honourable senators is that, from a number of comments made by Ministers and others, there is now a concerted effort on the part of the bureaucracy to overturn the motion that was passed and actually makes this type of thing occur.

I draw this to the attention of the Senate because I believe that if we give in to this move-in other words, if we do not demand the continuation of this in the next Parliament-it would be a prime example of a Yes Minister operation having won out. There is now a backlash from the bureaucracy. People in the bureaucracy do not like the scrutiny of these Acts that is now being exercised by the Parliament and they are now seeking to use a range of devices. Ministers, who presumably know very little about what they are saying, are using the words put into their mouths by the bureaucrats. I, for one, would indicate that there will be a long fight to retain this provision.
Under the finance item, the following interesting comment is made in relation to the Parliamentary Contributory Superannuation Amendment Act:

These provisions relate to benefits payable to parliamentarians who are covered by both State and Commonwealth parliamentary superannuation schemes. Negotiations with the States over the provisions began in 1981 and have failed to produce agreement.

That is where the matter has stayed. It is a very good example of where a piece of legislation should be taken off the books. If the Government has no intention of doing anything about such a matter, and seemingly nothing is included in the reasons, it should be taken off the books. I say that because the lawyers in this country who advise ordinary Australian citizens have absolutely no way of knowing, unless they have looked at these things previously, which Acts have or have not been proclaimed. We are attempting in part by this method to give some certainty to lawyers, and through lawyers to citizens, of what Acts are or are not in force. Here is a very good example of a reason given in 1981 as to why nothing was likely to occur. There is no associated comment from the Government that it has any intention of taking this measure off the books, proceeding with it, amending it, or otherwise. I do not think it is good enough to give that type of reason to the Parliament.

I have already mentioned that officers in the Department of Primary Industries and Energy discovered last time around, and even the time before that, a number of Bills that they did not know existed. I am pleased that those Bills have been found in one drawer or another. I think one would have a great deal more confidence had they been found the first time around. The fact that even the Department could not find which Bills it had demonstrates very clearly the need for this return to order.

TALK.START.PARA: —One wonders why we passed them in the first place.

—Indeed, that is perfectly correct. A lot of the time of the Senate is taken up passing Bills which actually sit in various drawers or, in this case, in a filing cabinet that no-one knows exists. Under social security, on page 19 of the last return to order, after a long discussion as to why nothing had been done, the following comment was made in regard to the Social Security Legislation Amendment Act 1983:

SPEECH.PARA: A small group of clients has yet to receive forms requiring notification under section 163.

By the way, this Act was passed in 1983 and these people have not yet received their forms. I hope that, since this is a social security measure, they have not all died by now-but that might be the method by which this matter is finally resolved. The return to order further stated:
Commencement of the 1983 provisions would excuse those clients from notifying changed circumstances. Action is being taken to trace the clients and issue notices.

It was with bated breath that I turned to the social security item in the current document. I found exactly the same comments about the small group of clients and so forth and so on, and then the following comments:
Commencement of the 1983 provisions would excuse those clients from notifying changed circumstances. Action is continuing to be taken to trace the remaining clients . . .
So, we hang in there; it is still going on.

TALK.START.PARA: —With no indication of how many have been found.

—There is absolutely no indication of how many clients we are dealing with. However, it is pleasing to note that `action is continuing to be taken'. That is the only change in circumstances in six months. I hope that at some stage we finally find these remaining clients, whoever mysteriously they might be, so that a measure passed by the Parliament in 1983 might finally be proclaimed in 1989 or 1990-seven years on. I think that item indicates fairly clearly the need for this continuing overview.

SPEECH.PARA: This return to order contains 47 outstanding items that were there last time around. Surely it would be possible-and I think, quite frankly, the Senate would welcome this-to have some type of omnibus Bill to clear these measures off the books and to get us back to where we should be. The matters left would be those with good reason to be outstanding. In this regard, I draw attention to those pieces of legislation regarding the Companies Code. They are outstanding because of the continuing High Court of Australia case which has not yet been settled. That is a perfectly valid and respectable reason and one which I am sure the Senate finds very easy to accept.

I do not know whether Senator Puplick would agree with me when I say that a piece of legislation to clear off the books measures that have been sitting around for so long would be welcome. It would enable us to get back to a clean state with regard to legislation. We would then be able to scrutinise each new item that is added in a very clear and straightforward manner. We should not still have 47 outstanding measures. I do not believe that anyone should give the rather silly type of excuse that a department is still looking for clients with regard to a 1983 Bill. Quite frankly, it is not worth the effort on the part of the people in the bureaucracy who have to chase these things up.

We are looking at another election shortly and a new Parliament. A Bill introduced either in this Parliament or early in the next Parliament to clean up this matter would be a way of dealing with this matter with some expedition. I see creeping into some of these reasons and excuses a feeling on the part of the people who are writing them that they cannot get these matters off the books because of the legislative log jam. One way to overcome that might well be to put all these measures together in a Bill. I ask the Minister responsible to take this on board and to discuss it with other Ministers as a means of dealing with the outstanding items that we have.

Lastly, let me say that I welcome the moves that have been made in a number of departments to get rid of these pieces of legislation. There are also moves to get rid of a number of other pieces of legislation that we have on the Notice Paper. It is good to see that action is finally being taken with regard to a number of these matters, although it is not enough. Indeed, some departments seem to have taken absolutely no notice at all. I give notice that next time around I actually want to go through in detail some of the departments that have made absolutely no moves whatsoever with regard to this return to order.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Macklin and I are a sort of double act on this matter. We have been for some little time. I support the suggestion that the honourable senator has made for something which might well be called the Statute Laws (Miscellaneous Repeal) Act to be introduced on a regular basis to deal with these matters. Once again, I want to indicate my appreciation of the work that the Clerks, in particular, have done to produce this document, entitled Unproclaimed Legislation. My only caveat or qualification is that it would facilitate our work if the document were dated and perhaps given a volume number. I am trying to work out which of the previous documents headed `Unproclaimed Legislation', is the last and which the first, and that would have been facilitated if the reports had been dated or given some appropriate number.

SPEECH.PARA: Like Senator Macklin, I want to spend a short time dealing with one or two of the Acts referred to. The first Act referred to in the document is the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Amendment Act 1987. We are told that paragraph 23 (1) (ea) has not been proclaimed because the Government now wants to undertake what the document refers to as `further consideration of the effects of the provision'. In other words, the Parliament has passed the Act because the Government said it needed to pass that legislation. The Government is now suddenly waking up to the fact that it may have some consequence that it did not anticipate would be the case when the legislation was passed. As a result, the proclamation of the Act is being held up. Frankly, I believe that these are the sorts of things that we should expect departments to anticipate; they should not be cases where, after the event, someone starts to think, `Well, what the hell have we now passed? What does it actually mean? What will be its effects?'.

Secondly, I refer to my old favourite, the Naval Properties Transfer Act 1925, still unproclaimed. We are now told that, because in 1985 the New South Wales Government granted an `easement in gross'-whatever the hell an `easement in gross' means-that protects the Commonwealth's maritime rights, the Act is no longer necessary. I suppose that the rendering unnecessary over a six-decade period is something which, again, should not have been allowed to drag on for as long as it has. Before I go further, I want to say that in relation to these sorts of cases, there are plenty of opportunities in legislation that comes before us to include a schedule in relation to a particular department that actually deals with the question of Acts or parts of Acts that can be repealed because they are redundant or superseded. That sort of provision can easily be tacked on as part of an Act otherwise before us.

I now turn to another old favourite of mine-the Koongarra Project Area Act 1981, section 3. In the unfortunate circumstances that he be given the opportunity to make further decisions about uranium mining, the Minister will undoubtedly find it ironic that this part of the Act has not been proclaimed. In fact, he will have it available to him for the purposes of proclamation when he gets around to completing his successful campaign, waged in association with the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button), for a review of the Australian Labor Party's uranium policy. It will be the supreme irony that the failure to proclaim has led to a situation that will in fact facilitate something we have been saying ought to have been the case all along. Once section 3 is proclaimed, the decision, if necessary, to proceed with uranium mining at Koongarra will be facilitated.

I now turn to the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation Amendment Act 1986. Three sections of this Act have not been proclaimed. Indeed, the document states that consideration will now be given to whether they should be proclaimed, repealed or amended. They deal with the question of employment within the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation (ASIO) and the change of arrangements from contractual to statutory arrangements. If there is one thing that will bring into real focus the question of the role of the Parliament, it is where legislation related to something as sensitive and delicate as ASIO and security arrangements can be passed by the Parliament, believing that it is exercising its proper authority over the security services of the country, and then the bureaucrats simply refuse to proclaim such legislation. When it is getting on to three years since an Act was passed, and important issues have simply been set aside by the bureaucracy, some very considerable problems will arise.

The points I was making about the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Amendment Act could also be made about the Circuit Layouts Act 1989 where, again, areas have not been proclaimed because it is believed, in retrospect, that some technical deficiencies have now arisen and need to be addressed. Those technical adjustments, to which the Unproclaimed Legislation document refers may or may not be significant; we do not know. However, we are entitled to believe in advance of legislation being introduced that, in fact, the Government has comprehended such matters.

Indeed, the same may be said for the unproclaimed sections of the Copyright Amendment Act 1989 which we are told will not be proclaimed until after certain regulations have been drawn up. Again, it seems to me entirely possible for a properly organised legislative service and properly organised government to have regulations available the moment Acts are passed. There is simply no reason why we should have to wait until all the procedures have been dealt with and then start de novo in terms of regulations, get the regulations in place and make the former dependent on the latter for its proclamation. Again, the Government should be able to anticipate such circumstances.

I now turn to the Customs Amendment Act 1979. A period of 10 years has now elapsed, and yet the amendments to the Customs Act relating to the power to detain and search persons who are reasonably suspected of having prohibited imports-that is, drugs-internally concealed in their bodies have not been dealt with. How can a government claim that it is taking action in relation to drug abuse, drug smuggling and control of the Australian Customs Service if in fact the Parliament has passed 10 years ago legislation empowering customs officers to do certain things, yet that legislation is still not proclaimed?

I now come to the last two points that I want to make, the first of which was referred to by Senator Macklin. I am talking about the group of Acts related to the Minerals (Submerged Land) Act 1981. At page 17, the Unproclaimed Legislation document states:
The associated Acts were overlooked in previous returns to order.

In other words, the department responsible for the administration of significant Acts of Parliament now claims that it simply overlooked the fact that these Acts were some- how not actually proclaimed. They have been enacted and passed by the Parliament. At the time it was undoubtedly said that it was absolutely vital and essential that they be passed by the Parliament and that democracy or the world as we know it would come to an end if they were not passed. They have undoubtedly been printed. I have not had the chance to see whether they have been circulated and I have them in a book of Acts-the 1981 volume or the loose-leaf version of the whole thing. Nevertheless, one would think they would be there. Yet, whereas we might have used the last two documents as a check list as to whether these things were alive and well, we find, only when the third of these reports comes to us, that this whole batch of Acts relating to a very important part of the natural resources area has not been dealt with.

The final Act to which I refer is the Broadcasting and Television Amendment Act 1985, section 14 (2) of which authorised the conduct of area inquiries. The Government is undoubtedly concerned that if it reviews this area it will find that, if it had actually proclaimed this section of the Act and allowed the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal to get on with the conduct of area inquiries, it would have saved itself some of the difficulties which are now attendant upon the mess now facing the Tribunal.

The Senate has played an important role in maintaining some oversight of this matter. I have referred on previous occasions to the work of the Deputy Clerk, Anne Lynch. Her original article, which appeared in the House Magazine on 13 May 1987, entitled `Proclamation of Acts-When . . . How . . . If?' was updated in the House Magazine on 30 August 1989 in an article entitled `Legislation by Proclamation-revisited'. It will be interesting to see what the third article has to say about all of these matters.

I conclude by correcting one of my opening remarks. Lest it be thought-heaven forfend-that the Clerks' office has been deficient in any sense in failing to provide proper dating or enumeration of these documents, I am now advised that such documents are prepared by the Government. Once again, it is the executive arm-not the legislative arm-which is grievously at fault in this particular matter. I would not for a moment dare to reflect other than upon the executive arm rather than the legislative arm. I simply repeat that it is clear that the Government has prepared these documents and they ought to be dated. They are documents of public information and record. It is necessary to understand what is going on in order to deal with them in a proper and sequential fashion. That cannot be done where there is no access to adequate dating and no indication of which report we now have.

That having been said, I believe that the Senate will have an important role to continue to play in the oversight of this matter. I support what Senator Macklin said about the need to tidy up, by a comprehensive repeal Act, all of those things which are genuinely otiose and which can be effectively dealt with in that fashion. I believe that the principle of coming back to us and saying, `These are the unintended consequences of what we said were vital' is not good enough. Least of all is it good enough for departments to tell us now that, on the third time around, they have found another batch of Acts for which they are responsible which have not been proclaimed and which they did not know about on the two previous occasions.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Committee is now considering the votes from Estimates Committee D for the Department of the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories. I move the following motion:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Committee, having considered the Report of Estimates Committee D, is of the opinion that it is a matter of regret that the instructions given by the Minister (Senator Richardson) to officers of his Department in relation to Coronation Hill were of such a nature as to prevent them from answering questions of a purely factual nature, including the confirmation of details presented in the Estimates Committee documents themselves, and the Committee therefore recommends that the Senate adopt the view of Estimates Committee D contained in paragraph 9 of its Report that:
``on future occasions, restrictions on comment of this type should not apply to matters of fact''.

As it may subsequently facilitate the Government's consideration of matters, let me say that my indication from Senator Haines is that the motion is supported broadly by the Australian Democrats. I wish therefore to commence my remarks on a number of matters relating to this Department with an analysis of the background that has caused me to move this motion. Senate Committee D sat on 5 October 1989. During that day the Cabinet was properly concerned with the resolution of matters relating to final Government decisions, or almost final Government decisions, about the future of Coronation Hill. In the course of my asking questions of officers of the Department, a number of exchanges occurred which simply put the matter on record. At page D127 of Estimates Committee D Hansard of 5 October one sees the following exchange:

TALK.START.PARA: —I come to some questions which undoubtedly in large part you will be quite properly not in a position to answer. They relate to Coronation Hill.

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Blunn, the Secretary to the Department, replied:
Senator, if I may say so before you go any further, my Minister has instructed me to answer no questions at all on Coronation Hill.

I subsequently asked whether Dr Roy Green from the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation's Institute of Natural Resources and Environment had transmitted to the Department of the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories a letter setting out the CSIRO view about the Coronation Hill proposal. Mr Blunn replied:
Senator, I regret that under the instructions given to me by the Minister I cannot answer any questions on Coronation Hill.
I then asked another question and Senator Bolkus, the Minister on duty at the time, said:
Mr Chairman, the clear position as put by Mr Blunn is that he will not be answering any questions on Coronation Hill.
The dialogue then continued:

TALK.START.PARA: —I see. That, I take it, includes the questions of fact as to matters which are on the public record.
—All matters of fact are fact until disputed, Senator Puplick. The fact is that we, as indicated to the Committee, cannot answer any question in relation to Coronation Hill.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not want to pursue that part of the hearing further. I simply refer to questions which I then sought to ask of Mr Fry, the Supervising Scientist for the Alligator Rivers region. The questions are set out on page D133 as follows:

TALK.START.PARA: —Are you in a position to answer any questions in relation to the resources or expenditure involved for the OSS in regard to work currently, or in the last couple of months, being undertaken in the conservation zone? Or is that part of the interdict?

SPEECH.PARA: By `interdict' I meant the instruction given by the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories (Senator Richardson) that questions were not to be answered. The Hansard report continues:
Mr Fry-I am not sure. There are figures in the explanatory memorandum, are there not?

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, but the fact that things are in the explanatory memorandum--

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Fry-May I seek advice on that?

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, please do.

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Blunn-Regretfully, I think it would be covered by the Minister's direction.

I was asking Mr Fry questions not about his opinion but about expenditure involved in work being undertaken at that time or in the previous couple of months, which were matters of public fact. I was asking how much money was involved, which is the very purpose of Estimates committees. The answer was, `I am not allowed to give you any information'.
The same thing occurred when Professor Derek Ovington, the Director of the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service, was before us. At page D167 I asked:
. . . Professor Ovington, you are under the same interdict as Mr Fry and the Secretary in relation to comments about Coronation Hill?
Professor Ovington answered:
It is my understanding that that is the case.

At page D173 I asked questions of Mr Kelleher, who is the Chief Executive Officer of the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority and who has also had extensive experience in his capacity as Chairman of the Australian committee dealing with matters relating to the International Union for Conservation of Nature and Natural Resources. I asked:
Mr Kelleher, what can you tell me about Coronation Hill?
Mr Kelleher replied:
Nothing. I understand that I am not supposed to answer any questions.

I do not for a moment dispute in any sense the right of the Minister to give instructions to his Department and its officers to decline to answer questions on government policy. That is not the purpose of Estimates committee investigations. That is not the purpose of the committees as they were originally established, although everybody knows that part and parcel of the game afoot is to find out from departmental officers answers to questions on government policy that one cannot get by other means. I believe that it is proper for a Minister to instruct his department and its officers not to answer questions which relate to government policy. But I do not believe that it is proper for a Minister to instruct his Department or its officers to confirm or fail to confirm matters of fact or to fail to give responses to matters of fact that are contained in Estimates committee documents.

The Estimates Committee documents themselves contain information about Coronation Hill. They are the documents provided to us upon which our questions are supposed to be based. Let me take, for example, page 429 of the explanatory notes. Subprogram 9.5 deals primarily with natural resource management questions and is part of a larger program. Under the heading `Natural Resources Management', it is stated:
Appropriate contributions will be made to Government decisions on:
the review of the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service;
the boundaries of the Conservation Zone associated with the Kakadu National Park; and
the assessment of the environmental impact of the Coronation Hill project in the Kakadu Conservation Zone.

In other words, the documents themselves tell us what is going on, what the Department is seeking an appropriation for, and invite specific questions. When this matter was then considered by Estimates Committee D, it reported in paragraph 9 of its report presented to the Senate:

The Committee notes that Senator Richardson was not at the Committee hearing when the issue of Coronation Hill arose because Cabinet was considering the same issue at that time. Government policy on the matter was stated by the Prime Minister in a press release issued during the course of the Committee's hearing. The Committee is of the view that, on future occasions, restrictions on comment of this type should not apply to matters of fact. However, the Committee considers that, in these circumstances, the general thrust of the Minister's instruction was understandable.

I do not qualify that; I do not disagree with that. I make these points: firstly, in my view the Committee should have been invited by the Minister to return to the question of Coronation Hill after the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) had put out a press statement in which the Cabinet decision was announced. In other words, the Committee was still in session and, indeed, met for quite some hours subsequently and should have been invited to return to the matters which were prevented from being exposed in the Committee hearings because they were under consideration by Cabinet, after Cabinet had, in fact, not only decided the matter but also actually put out a formal statement. It was not a matter of our seeking what was the Cabinet decision before it was announced. The Cabinet decision was announced by the Prime Minister in a press release which was made at the time that the Committee was still in session. In my view the Committee Chairman and the Minister should have invited the Committee to return to a consideration of the matter at that stage. Nevertheless, that is past. We will know better should any subsequent similar event arise.
The whole of Estimates Committee D-not just I or the Opposition members; its three Labor members, along with the three non-Labor members-concluded:
The Committee is of the view that, on future occasions, restrictions on comment of this type should not apply to matters of fact.

The motion which I have moved does not in any sense seek to censure or condemn Senator Richardson. It simply says that it is a matter of regret that his instructions were of such a nature as to prevent his officers from answering questions of a purely factual nature. It invites the Senate to adopt the view expressed by its own Committee in its report to the Senate that on future occasions restrictions on comment of this type should not apply to matters of fact. I believe that, if we proceed along those lines to make it quite clear that the Senate believes that ministerial instructions not to answer questions should relate only to matters of policy and that instructions should not be given to prevent officers answering in relation to matters of fact, we will have some clarification of where the demarcation line for the conduct of Estimates committees lies. It is a method of inviting Ministers to determine, if they wish to prohibit their officers from answering questions, that that prohibition does not extend to the confirmation or otherwise of matters of fact and, in particular, matters of fact which arise specifically from the information which is contained in the Estimates committee papers from which we are working at the time.

I have formally moved that motion. I presume that it will not come to a vote until we conclude the whole debate in relation to Estimates Committee D. I have a number of other matters to raise in relation to Estimates Committee D. We can deal with those in due course. I have formally moved that motion. I believe that the Senate will at least be taking some steps to clarify exactly how it believes its committees should operate in that regard with the passage of that motion which, as I say, I understand will be supported by the Australian Democrats.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Puplick, we have the option of putting your motion at the end of the debate or setting it aside and dealing with it when the vote is taken. It is for the Committee to decide how it would prefer to deal with it.
—Perhaps the Minister could indicate.
—I do not think that, in any event, the Government would want to press the matter to a vote, although I would like to make some points about the motion which Senator Puplick has moved.

—If the Government is not intending to press the matter to a vote, it might be easier for the Minister to comment and for the motion to be then put, if that is in order. If a vote is not going to be taken and it can be passed on the voices, we will then just proceed with the consideration of the remainder of the appropriations to be considered by the Committee.
—We can do that.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALKER.NAME: Senator RICHARDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories)

TALK.START.PARA: —I said in response to a question from Senator Puplick the day after the incident to which he is now referring occurred that I regretted having to give the instruction to the Secretary to my Department in the way that I did. I believe that the motion put forward by Senator Puplick would be of assistance to the Senate in future. I think it should be acknowledged that we were dealing with an extraordinary situation where Cabinet happened to be dealing with Coronation Hill at the very time Estimates Committee D was meeting. In the seven years I have had here, that has not happened before. I do not think it is normal, nor do I think it is likely to happen again.

SPEECH.PARA: In listening to what Senator Puplick has just said, I think that it does raise a fundamental difficulty for officers even in proceeding in the way in which he has just suggested. Senator Puplick spoke of the difference between fact and policy in questions being put to officers. Of course, he is right. But in my experience there are three sorts of questions that are asked of officers: they are questions of fact, of policy and of opinion. The reality is that, irrespective of the guidelines laid down in the Senate for the way that Senate Estimates committees should be conducted, they have, over time, evolved into a quite adversarial process. There is no question that officers are put under the microscope, at times in fairly heated discussion. It is certainly my experience that the boundary between fact and opinion is almost impossible to define.
I can assert some facts about Coronation Hill that I know are disputed not just by members of the Opposition, but even by some--

TALK.START.PARA: —How can they be facts if they are disputed?

—Exactly. It is for that very reason that in a court case a whole process is laid down-it sometimes takes 12 months before something goes to court-just to make sure that both sides acknowledge the facts. In the world of science and biology ascertaining a fact can take years. People write learned papers on whether or not something which is asserted by another is a fact. There is no question in the case of Coronation Hill that a number of the facts that I have asserted were challenged. Fortunately, when it came to the crunch the majority accepted that what I was saying was true. There is no doubt that opinion would have been called for, and almost certainly would still be called for, if the Senate is to follow the wording of Senator Puplick's motion.

SPEECH.PARA: As I have said, the Government will not oppose the motion. But I ask that all honourable senators consider that line between fact and opinion. It is a very difficult line to draw. I have not known of its having been drawn properly before. While Senator Puplick was speaking I was sitting here thinking and I still cannot work out just how I would define it. While the Government will not oppose the motion, I still believe that this will present some difficulties for officers and Ministers in the future, let alone for the committees that have to deal with the questions before them. To put this matter into some sort of perspective, I also think that as Senator Puplick was asking Mr Kelleher questions-or was about to ask Mr Kelleher questions-that almost certainly takes us into the realm of opinion because Mr Kelleher had not been dealing with any of the Coronation Hill issues directly. So virtually whatever Senator Puplick was going to ask Mr Kelleher had to be opinion.

TALK.START.PARA: —You should not assume I was going to ask him anything.

—I hope that Senator Puplick would not be wasting anyone's time, so I assume that he would have asked Mr Kelleher something. I believe it is a problem. I just hope that it is one that the Senate gives some earnest consideration to. I could go through some very learned arguments that I have on this question and quote Odgers Australian Senate Practice and a whole host of things. I do not propose to take up the time of the Senate in doing so. I just urge honourable senators to consider the difference between fact and opinion which I know will be of importance on many future occasions.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The only phrase that Senator Richardson did not use in his reply was the great Australian tautology `the true facts'. There are facts and there are non-facts or there are statements which are facts and there are statements which are not facts. If the question is, `How much did you spend on X?', the answer is a certain number of dollars. The question, `Do you believe that the money was well spent?' may indeed be a matter of opinion on the part of the officers. It may be legitimate for the Minister on duty to intervene and to say, `As a matter of fact it is the opinion of the Government that all of its money is well spent'. Undoubtedly we can chase that argument around for a considerable time.

SPEECH.PARA: Frankly, the logic of what Senator Richardson has said, if taken through to its inevitable conclusion, would be very largely to render the whole Estimates committee process unworkable because in truth what would occur is that we would have the Estimates committee document which would allegedly be the presentation of the facts and we would not need to have questions asked at Estimates committees. We could simply say, `Those are the facts; what other facts do you want? Put down a question on notice and we will give you the facts'. The process of Estimates committee hearings is largely to try to tease out explanations of what the purely factual statements about dollars and cents expenditure in the Estimates committee papers actually mean.

TALK.START.PARA: —And what they hide.

—Or, as Senator Michael Baume says, what they do not reveal as much as what they do reveal. I think that is well understood by all of us. I do not believe that it is difficult to establish a fairly easily comprehended set of principles which are largely based on simply commonsense as to what is a fact, what is a matter of opinion and what is a matter of policy. That is why we have chairmen at these committees; that is why we have Ministers on duty; that is why over time the Senate has developed a set of procedures for handling these matters. I believe that the passage of this motion will simply facilitate a clear indication that where matters are matters of fact and information has been sought on a purely factual basis, they should be provided and Ministers should not instruct officers not to answer questions purely of fact.

TALKER.NAME: Senator RICHARDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Puplick's reference to the great Australian tautology `true facts' has in `true fact' relevance here. If one looks at the South Alligator River immediately adjacent to Coronation Hill one finds two monitoring stations of effects on the river. One is operated by the Office of the Supervising Scientist (OSS), the other by the joint venturers. They are feet apart. From memory I would judge the distance at about 10 feet. These days I am supposed to give that distance in another form of measurement which I do not understand. Is three metres close to that distance?
—That is pretty right.

—I have spent about 45 minutes discussing these two stations with representatives of the OSS and the joint venturers because they measure in a slightly different way. Both sides would claim that their measurement of effect on the river is correct. Both sides would assert that it is a true fact. However, if the measurements come out differently one wonders how we assert which is the truer true-fact and which is the less true true-fact. It is very difficult. That is the point that I am trying to make. As I said, the Government is not opposing what Senator Puplick is putting down. I am just trying to bring to the attention of the Senate the fact that there are difficulties particularly, as was the case on this occasion, when we were--
—Just plead guilty as charged.
—I have nothing to plead guilty to-nothing whatsoever.
—Holding the Senate in contempt.

—I did not hold anything in contempt. If honourable senators opposite thought I did they would be moving a much stronger motion than this one. I did not hold anyone in contempt. I was faced with a very difficult situation with Cabinet discussing this matter at the time when the Estimates Committee met.
—Political difficulty.

—No, not politically difficult. If that is the view that Senator Michael Baume wishes to take, we had better get onto Odgers and Australian Senate Practice. There is absolutely no doubt whatsoever that when it comes to the production of documents or information when they are related to Cabinet discussions the precedents are endless. They are not produced prior to Cabinet having discussed the matter and made a decision. Senator Baume is wrong but that is not unusual. All I am trying to say is that the way Estimates committees have developed, in particular on this occasion, would have made it very difficult for the Chairman, let alone the Minister, who was not the Minister who had carriage of the issue, to make the judgments that Senator Puplick thinks are so easy. Nonetheless, the Government is not opposing the motion and I will say no more.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —Having got that matter out of the way, I intend to make one final observation. That is quite simply to take Senator Richardson's example. It is possible for facts to conflict if the two stations to which Senator Richardson referred measure different things at different locations and using different methods.
—They are measuring the same thing in different ways.

—If they measure the same thing at two different places using two different methods, it is possible that we will get two sets of results. It then becomes a matter of judgment, not as to which one is wrong, but as to which one is to be taken as the basis for action. But the confirmation that facts are in conflict is something that people ought to know. Much as I am tempted to give a lengthy dissertation on Mr Heisenberg's uncertainty principle at this stage, I shall refrain from doing so. I simply ask for certain matters regarding Coronation Hill, only in the very broadest sense. I do not intend to pursue the debate about Coronation Hill under this heading.

SPEECH.PARA: However, I ask Senator Richardson the following: firstly, can he inform this chamber when Professor Taylor's review of the Office of the Supervising Scientist will be completed, and will the review document relating to the OSS be made a public document? Secondly, is he able to indicate, in relation to the whole of his portfolio area, those bodies that have been reviewed, the progress of Government consideration and whether the review documents themselves have been made public? I know that some of them have; indeed, some of them have been provided to me, and I am extremely grateful for that. There are large numbers of areas of the Minister's Department, such as the Australian National Library, the Australian National Gallery and other bits and pieces which have been reviewed. I would just like to have some comprehensive response to the question whether all those reviews have been completed. Thirdly, is Senator Richardson prepared to provide publicly a copy of the report, letter or communication which went from Dr Roy Green of the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation Institute of Natural Resources and Environment to his Department relating to the CSIRO evaluation in regard to certain matters at Coronation Hill?

TALK.START.PARA: —I think the review from Dr Taylor was received in my office in the last 24 hours or something like that. It is hot off the press and has just arrived. I would like a week or two to consider it without the heat of public debate, but I shall table it in this chamber before we get up this year. If the honourable senator gives me a couple of weeks, I will sort that out.

SPEECH.PARA: I can recall the Australian National Library, the Australian National Gallery and the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service having been reviewed. There was also a review on some aspects of tourism. That was quite some time back; I do not actually recall precisely when, but I will endeavour to check that for the honourable senator. As far as I am concerned, it is not possible when reviewing these instrumentalities to do a secret job. If we are to have a proper debate the documents ought to be made public. I shall endeavour to ensure that all those reviews are tabled in this chamber so that the honourable senator can have a look at them. I was asked about a copy of a letter from Dr Green to my Department. Of course, it is normal practice at Estimates committee hearings to ask the sender, not the receiver. If the sender is happy for that letter to be released, so am I.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I take it from that answer that the Minister will ask the sender.
—I am happy to do that.

—I thank the Minister. As I have said, the debate about Coronation Hill is essentially in the political domain rather than in the domain of further detailed information, and I do not propose to use this opportunity to take it further at this stage. Adequate opportunity will be provided, no doubt, in the weeks and months ahead.

SPEECH.PARA: I turn next to another matter which has been raised in the report of Estimates Committee D; that is, the question of the tendency of officers in the Department to write essays in place of succinct statements about parts of their portfolio. Far be it from me to believe that the arts department is in any sense more inclined to have people within it given to writing essays than any other department. I wanted to make reference to something which appears in Estimates Committee D papers relating to the film industry, not just because it is, in my judgment, an example of where people have gone overboard in writing, but because one does not really know what the status of some matters is. For example, we do not know whether this is the official view of the Government in relation to those matters. I refer to page 198 of the explanatory notes for the Estimates Committee, which deals with the question of film development and production support, part of the overall program which deals with the Australian Film Commission. At this stage I will not even take this opportunity to reflect on Mr Adams's latest comments about who may or may not bear a resemblance to Caligula in dealing with these matters, but I wish to quote from the words that appear in the document. In relation to the film development and production support program, it says:

An active Australian film and television industry dates from the 1970's when Government support was provided to revitalise production activity of a locally relevant cultural nature. As a relatively new industry, it is still without established lines of credit from financial institutions; the available pool of skilled personnel is limited; it operates in a small market and has not yet achieved regular access to the international market.

That is a matter of seven lines, and one could dispute almost every line. That `an active Australian film and television industry dates from the 1970s', I think, is a matter of debate, particularly in relation to the Australian television industry'. `When Government support was provided to revitalise production activity', is stated as if one were automatically the consequence of the other. The next part is `of a locally relevant cultural nature'. Again, if one looks at television production, the question of what is `of a relevant cultural nature' raises more questions than it answers. `As a relatively new industry', is the next part of the quote. In fact, in terms of the Australian film industry we are dealing with one of the oldest film industries in the world. Productions which occurred in the 1890s, whether it was the Lumiere brothers' work, whether it was the production of the first film of the Manly ferry arrival, or the 1896 Melbourne Cup--

TALK.START.PARA: —Salvation Army.

—Whether it was the Salvation Army's first feature film, Soldiers of the Cross, or whether it was the first really well-developed feature film of the Tait brothers, The Kelly Gang-these are matters of some pride within the Australian film industry. It does not need to be told that it is a relatively new industry. The next part of the quote is, `without established lines of credit from financial institutions'. Again that is certainly open to a considerable amount of debate. We then have, `the available pool of skilled personnel is limited'. It depends on what we define as `skilled personnel'. If `skilled personnel' are taken to be actors and actresses, the pool is not limited; in fact, the pool is in oversupply. The quote continues, `it operates in a small market and has not yet achieved regular access to the international market'. Yet for years we have been providing money for promotions at film festivals. We have an extraordinarily good record. Indeed, on page 198 of the explanatory notes we find this statement of the Australian film industry:

SPEECH.PARA: it . . . has not yet achieved regular access to the international market.
On page 200 of that document we find:
Films funded through the Special Production Fund have had notable exposure in world film festivals . . .

Frankly, this is a question of which of those two statements is a statement of fact. I suspect that the statement of fact is that it has had notable exposure in world film festivals and that the business of the Australian film industry not having achieved regular access to the international market is simply not true.
I could go on about this at some length, but the Estimates Committee itself dealt with this matter. At page 210 of the explanatory notes, basically within the same program, we find:
As a relatively recent phenomenon, film has yet to be widely acknowledged and evaluated as an art form.

Senator Richardson himself in answering a question said that he did not agree that it was a relatively recent phenomenon. He conceded that in the course of the debate. I do not seek to make anything more of it; I simply draw attention once again to the fact that the Estimates Committee in its report at paragraph 11 noted that this was the second year in which this matter had been drawn to the attention of the Department. The Committee accepted the Minister's response that there is a fine line to be drawn between unnecessarily waxing lyrical on the pages of Estimates Committee documents and yet at the same time recognising the need to justify the program.

The Committee noted with approval the Minister's promise that the problem would be addressed in next year's explanatory notes. I certainly look forward to that. However, I think it needs to be kept in mind that this is the second occasion this has occurred. This assurance was given last year. It simply makes matters much more difficult. We are already dealing with a document in relation to this Department which runs to 547 pages. I know the technique of putting out as much paper as we possibly can in order to ensure that people are buried by it. This is not the only department that Estimates Committee D has had to deal with. The Department of Defence and the defence science and personnel portfolio have to be dealt with also. I think that the Minister would undoubtedly have a burning passion in his heart for the number of trees that have gone into the production of this particular document. I think there is some scope for those matters to be addressed in the future.

I wish now, rather than making a large number of separate interventions-I have made the point I wanted to make in relation to the nature of the documents themselves-to raise a question. I admit I am really seeking some information because the material that has been given to me does not provide adequate information. It relates to any grants made through the Minister's Department, either directly or as a result of certain bicentennial activities, for the purchase of a motor yacht by the name of Eva and whether any assistance was given for the purchase of this vessel. I understand that money used for its purchase may have been bicentennial money-this is where the confusion arises in terms of who has lingering responsibility for answering questions about bicentennial money activities-and that the vessel was originally in the possession of Societe Generale Australia Ltd. I believe it was auctioned and purchased with the use of bicentennial money for a figure of $1.2m and subsequently resold for between $4m and $6m.

I do not know anything further at this stage about that, although I am seeking to have some inquiries made. The person who I believe both purchased and sold the vessel holds a very senior position as a result of his appointment to one of the statutory authorities which is within the Minister's competence and purview. I will happily indicate privately to the Minister who the individual is.

TALK.START.PARA: —Do you mean Ena?
—No.
—I know someone who owns a boat called Ena.

—In that case we may well be talking about precisely the same matter. As I say, I will provide the Minister with the name of the individual and he can undertake such inquiries as he regards necessary. I do not think it is proper for me to use this forum to name the individual concerned.

SPEECH.PARA: The other matter that I want to raise at this stage concerns one of Senator Richardson's friends, the Chairman of the Council of the Australian National Gallery. I refer to the foreword to the Gallery report. I ask the Minister whether he is prepared to indicate to the Senate on this occasion whether he shares the opinion which Mr Whitlam presents on page 7 of the annual report of the Gallery for 1988-89 in these terms:
The National Gallery Act is not the only Act which Finance has set out to subvert in its restricted and distorted view of Federal responsibilities.

The Minister and the officers of his Department undoubtedly share that view. I know that the distinguished Secretary to the Department has issued one press statement in relation to the Department of Finance report What Price Heritage? I like the draft statement better than the final statement, but so be it. However, I am interested as to whether the Department or the Minister intends to give any more detailed response to the Finance Department report What Price Heritage?-whether that now slips into the general mainstream of the debate or whether it is intended that the Minister for the Arts, Tourism and Territories (Mr Holding), Senator Richardson as the senior Minister in the area or the Department separately will be putting out a detailed statement in relation to that matter.
Finally, I draw attention to the question of the membership of the Council of the Australian National Gallery. Mr Whitlam in his foreword says:
There has not been an artist serving on the Council since the retirement of Ms Maddock, nor an art historian since the retirement of Professor Margaret Plant on 3 July 1987.

I think that that is not correct. I think that a recent appointment, that of Miss Marika, may well be taken to be the appointment of an artist, although her area of expertise relates to Aboriginal art. She is a museum curator and also a practising artist. For the sake of the public record, the annual report having indicated that there was not an artist on the Council of the Gallery, that should simply be brought up to date. I take it that the Minister can quite simply confirm that Miss Marika is an artist and perhaps indicate to me whether there is any Government policy requiring or favouring the appointment of practising artists to the Council of the National Gallery or whether, if an artist or an art historian happens to be appointed, that is simply incidental rather than the result of a deliberate attempt to seek somebody with those particular skills to be regularly represented on the Council of the Gallery.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am sure Senator Button would be delighted to hear it. The matter I wish to pursue-and hopefully this will be my last contribution on this portfolio area-is the question of ongoing funding for environmental research. The Committee would be aware that in October 1989 the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation (CSIRO) made a submission to the Australian Science and Technology Council which had been asked by the Government to review the state of environmental research in Australia. This has been the subject of some discussions and comments made by Senator Button at Question Time. The CSIRO submission is disturbing for one of two reasons: either because it draws attention to what is a deficiency in terms of the funding and the nature and the adequacy of environmental research being done by the CSIRO in Australia, if one believes the CSIRO; or, if not, because it raises questions about the intellectual integrity of the CSIRO in terms of whether its claims are, as Senator Button essentially characterises them, simply self-serving claims aimed at increasing its allocation in next year's Budget or getting some particular special vote in order to increase its resources. The CSIRO, in the summary of its submission, says:

SPEECH.PARA: Solutions to environmental problems will depend not only on environmental research, but on many other areas of research as well. The protection and restoration of the environment should be made a primary goal that underpins the conduct of Australian research in general, including rural, industrial, and minerals and energy research.

In some cases, environmental research has been essential to the identification of environmental problems; in many cases it is essential to their understanding; and in most cases research and its application are essential to the resolution through the development of better resource and environmental management and more environmental benign industries.

Australia possesses the necessary infrastructure for environmental research, but lacks the research capacity to assess adequately the environmental impact of agriculture, forestry, mining, industrial, tourist and urban activities and developments. We therefore cannot ensure the effective integration and reconciliation of economic and environmental objectives, on which, ultimately, the future health of the nation rests.

The CSIRO in that comment is saying, `We cannot provide any sort of guarantee that from our resources the public will be sufficiently informed or the Government will be sufficiently informed about these questions in order to allow them to make a balanced and proper decision'. The Canberra Times of 9 November reported this submission under the heading, `CSIRO says it cannot guarantee a future balance'. It is very important that we explore this a little further. One of the examples which the CSIRO submission gives in relation to things that it cannot do is research into koalas and the koala populations of Australia. It indicates, for example, that it is unable to provide the sort of baseline data which would be necessary in order to make effective decisions. The CSIRO, on page 13 of the submission, says:

We do not even know the distribution of one of our national symbols, the koala. Some 25% of our plants and at least 50% of our invertebrates remain undescribed. Invertebrates underpin the stability of the world's ecosystems. Hence they play a key role in determining how ecosystems respond to climate and other change.

Obviously, in dramatising this matter by referring to koalas, the CSIRO has proved the truth of the dictum that one can sell almost anything if one puts a cuddly bear on the front of it. It has taken advantage of that.

TALK.START.PARA: —It's the sizzle, not the sausage.

—Indeed. However, that has not been the only example given. I propose to refer at some length to the answer given by Mr Barry Jones to a question put on notice by Mr Langmore which appeared in the House of Representatives Hansard on 30 August 1989. Mr Jones was asked what had been the impact of Government funding cutbacks on the CSIRO Division of Wildlife and Ecology since mid-1985. The Minister is not directly responsible for this but it is, nevertheless, part of the environment portfolio. It is undoubtedly on the basis of information from CSIRO that the Minister undertakes the analysis of particular problems and comes to the conclusions upon which Government policy is based. After the dinner break I will be in a position to continue to analyse this matter a little further. By then the Minister and his officers will have had time to look at the House of Representatives Hansard and have all of the answers immediately to hand.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-Mr Temporary Chairman, I claim to have been seriously misrepresented and wish to make a personal explanation. On the channel 9 six o'clock news this evening, Mr Laurie Oakes purveyed the view that in the course of my remarks this afternoon in the matter of public importance debate I had given support to the Hawke-Keating Government on its interest rates policy. SPEECH.PARA: I simply want to put on the record what I said in the Senate this afternoon on this matter. I will quote from my pinks, which I have in front of me. I said:
We are not going to do anything irresponsible of that kind-
that is, signal during next year's election campaign an immediate and large fall in interest rates-

because we have said all along that there is no magic wand. TALK.START.PARA: —You can see the hand of aNiMaLS in that.
—I entirely agree with Senator Lewis's interjection.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to talk about other types of animals--
—Furry ones.

—Furry ones, as distinct from the hairy ones that inhabit the National Media Liaison Service. Before the suspension of the sitting for dinner I was drawing attention to the impact on environmental research which has been occasioned by the cutback in funds provided to the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation (CSIRO). I referred to the answer given by the Minister for Science, Customs and Small Business, Mr Barry Jones, to a question on notice on 31 August. He was asked to detail the impact on the CSIRO Division of Wildlife and Ecology since mid-1985 of the cuts in government funds. He indicated that certain cuts had been made in terms of research that was curtailed or terminated and research that was not commenced. What the Minister describes as important research curtailed or terminated includes research into the nature of mouse plagues, the cuts made to the national wildlife collection, the closing down of research on introduced pasture grasses in semi-arid regions, cutbacks in range land research with the loss of scientists working on woody weed effects, cuts in research into the ecology of native forests, bird pest research which had been stopped, research into kangaroo studies which had been reduced, nutritional and diet selection research into koalas which had been terminated, and research into vertebrate population dynamics in rainforests which had been terminated. All rabbit control research other than that funded by the Australian Wool Corporation had been terminated. Research into coastal dune stabilisation by vegetation had been terminated. Regional scale maintenance of kangaroo numbers can no longer be carried out. A recently initiated work on deer farming had been severely curtailed.

SPEECH.PARA: Important new initiatives which had not been commenced included research into the ecological dynamics in the Antarctic, development of benign methods of fertility control of wildlife, development via molecular biology approaches to introduce sterility in wild rabbits, research into lamb losses with and without fox and/or rabbit control, research into the influence of management initiated fires on forest wildlife species, restoration of mining sites, risk assessment of potential exotic disease outbreak, North Queensland rainforest inventory and mapping which has been deferred, developments in erosion forecasting, conservation management of arid mountain ranges, research into how to prevent species lost, and allocation and management of resources in the Australian coastal zone. The Minister, Mr Jones, indicated that as a result of these cutbacks:
Agricultural development is proceeding without due consideration for its sustainability.
He concludes:

Within Australia the ability of the division to provide the detailed information needed to develop the best national conservation policies is well short of what it should be and in some areas is virtually grinding to a halt.

Let us look at that litany set off against the Government's announced priorities. It talks to us about sustainability, about sustainable development, and its cuts have been such that the Minister Mr Jones says that agricultural development is proceeding without due consideration for its sustainability. We are told about the importance of soil conservation, and yet things like rabbit control, feral animal control and kangaroo population monitoring are not being undertaken. We are told about the importance of the Antarctic and yet ecosystem research in the Antarctic is being curtailed. We are told about the importance of genetic diversity and yet research into preventing species loss is not being undertaken. We are told that coastal zone management is important enough for the Resource Assessment Commission to get into it and yet research into coastal dune stabilisation and into matters related to management and control of the coastal zone is being cut. We are told how important the semi-arid lands of Australia are-indeed they are-yet research into pasture grasses in those areas is being cut back.

This litany which is, by the Minister's own admission, a result of cuts in government funding goes on apace. We see, for example, in the Australian of 31 October 1989 a story about Dr John Greenslade and a principal in the Entomology Division, Dr Bob Taylor, who have been told that funding for their research, which deals with things like the control of aphids, weeds, cockroaches and locusts, has been curtailed. Some of them have been sacked. They are told that this work is no longer central to CSIRO's effort. We saw stories in the Sydney Morning Herald on 22 November 1989 that Dr Tucker, the Chief of the Division of Atmospheric Research in CSIRO, has to go and talk to the Australian Conservation Foundation about how between them they can effectively lobby the Government to do something about their funding.

We see in the Australian on 20 November 1989, under the heading `CSIRO's key green funds ``left in the red'' ', that funding for environmental research has fallen by 54 per cent since 1982-83 and that the extra spending announced this year in the environment statement of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) did not make up for the cuts which have previously been imposed upon it. There has been a decline in funding of 40 per cent in real terms from 1979-80 to 1987-88, to $21.5m, having fallen from a peak of $46.3m.

As I have said, Senator Button has sought to make light of this matter by saying that it is all part of a special pleading on the part of CSIRO for additional funds. However, we know that in areas like ozone research the CSIRO had to cut back on research expenditure, and then when the thing became a political hot potato the Government was able to throw sums of money at it to try to restore the research effort. However, we cannot turn on and turn off research effort; we cannot find research workers and get back into the field after having made as many cuts to the CSIRO as has been the case. I refer to the editorial in today's Australian under the heading `Decisions in the dark'. It says:

But what is indisputable is that Australia faces a dangerous trend: the rate of spending on research is not even keeping close to the pace with political pressures for environment regulation, roadblocks to development, and spending on green projects.

As a result, critical environmental decisions increasingly are becoming leaps in the dark. Political leaders are placing the attractiveness of being seen to `do something' before the need to develop a solid scientific grounding for decision-making.

The editorial points to a number of examples. It points to decisions taken in New South Wales about ozone protection. It points to ideas floated by the Minister for Science, Customs and Small Business for a so-called carbon tax. It points to the Prime Minister's one billion trees program, and says:
What is the point in providing millions of dollars for planting trees while allowing CSIRO forestry research projects to be cut?

In terms of the overall integration of issues of environment policy with other Government policies-and this is not a matter which lies primarily within Senator Richardson's Department, as I speak about the cuts to CSIRO-and as the Government goes about allegedly putting together a coherent and developed environment policy, it cannot be pursuing environmental research in one department and cutting back in another department. It cannot be expected to make significant decisions about environmental matters without adequate data. That data will not be forthcoming if the sorts of cuts which are being imposed on the CSIRO, particularly in the areas of environmental research by the CSIRO, continue to be made. That is where I will leave my comments about that matter.

I want to conclude by asking the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories to comment on two other specific matters, to bring my remarks in this portfolio area to a close. I refer to the question of the International Antarctic Centre in Hobart. An advertisement was put out some time ago by this Centre under the heading `Antarctica-the lure of the frozen south. Come and experience Antarctica in Hobart at the new International Antarctic Centre. Planned opening October 1990.' I understand that, as a result of cutbacks made in arrangements for funding at both the Tasmanian State level and the Commonwealth level, this Centre will not be proceeding. I understand that there has been a decision that the Federal and Tasmanian governments have agreed that the financial resources needed to establish this Centre are not available and that, therefore, the project is to be indefinitely deferred. I would be grateful for some advice from the Minister as to whether in fact the Centre has been indefinitely deferred. If so, what are the reasons?

The last point I want to make arises directly from the report of the Estimates Committee on which we should be focusing, and undoubtedly you, Mr Chairman, require us primarily to focus our remarks on matters which are in the Estimates Committee reports. I refer to the almost total failure of the Department to provide annual reports prior to the conduct of the Estimates Committee hearings. Paragraph 4 of the Estimate's Committee report states:

The Committee did not receive advance copies of the annual reports of any portfolio agency, although this is a requirement of the guidelines for preparation of departmental annual reports. The Public Service Act (s. 25) makes these guidelines legally binding on departmental secretaries and their equivalents in other agencies. The Committee noted that the Department failed to meet this aspect of its legal obligation to report to Parliament.

While the Committee noted that the Department was diligent in providing other information, it also said that it had manifestly failed. Indeed, it was only today-and this has not yet been tabled in the Senate, I might add-that I received the annual report of the Australian Film, Television and Radio School. Frankly, the Minister and his departmental Secretary have an obligation which in fact is cast upon them by the Public Service Act and the guidelines, which apparently are legally binding on departmental Secretaries and their equivalents in the various agencies, to provide this information. The Senate Estimates Committee has seen fit to draw to the attention of the chamber the fact that the Committee did not receive advance copies of the annual reports for any portfolio agency.

Indeed, within this portfolio the agencies are quite numerous and in fact play significant roles. Indeed, most of our attention is focused on a number of those agencies. I am genuinely disappointed about this, because to date the Department of the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories has had an extremely good record in the way in which it has dealt with Estimates committees. The Secretary and officers of the Department have been assiduous in providing information as and when requested. It is disappointing that on this occasion these reports were not available, primarily from the agencies and statutory authorities to which I have referred.

I regret that the Committee has had to take this matter to the stage of making a report to the Senate and, in fact, noting that the Department had failed to meet this aspect of its legal obligations to report to Parliament. I hope that there will be some explanation of why this is the case; that there will be some indication that at least the Department understands its responsibility; that the Minister-at least so long as he remains Minister-is cognisant of his responsibilities; and that we will not be placed in this position of once again having to look at these major and important cultural and environmental institutions without the benefit of the annual reports to which this Parliament is entitled and where in fact legal obligations to provide them in a proper and timely fashion are cast upon the responsible officers.
