TALKER.NAME: Senator RICHARDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories)

TALK.START.PARA: —The main thrust of Senator Puplick's contribution concerned this question of funds for environmental research and naturally enough he referred to the submission by the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation (CSIRO) in relation to the Australian Science and Technology Council (ASTEC) review into environmental research in Australia. The first point to make is that the very fact that the Government asked for such a review indicated that, in the Government's view, there were some problems in terms of the length, breadth and depth of our knowledge about research into environmental matters. So we asked the scientific community to tell us what they thought of it.

SPEECH.PARA: In evaluating the state of environmental research, a number of factors must be taken into account. One of them, of course, concerns what research is done by the CSIRO. We will no doubt be able to contrast the view of the CSIRO of its role with the general view of the Government as to where and how environmental research ought to be conducted. The main point to make here is that, while it might not be in accord with all of CSIRO's wishes, environmental research is conducted by a number of government agencies-and not wholly and solely by the CSIRO. Obviously it would like to do it all-I understand that-but it has never been the case. In fact, in most recent times it has probably been less the case.

Senator Puplick referred to a range of areas of research. I will not attempt to cover them all. Having taken some notes of what Senator Puplick was saying, there are a few areas I can refer to. First, he referred to the monitoring of kangaroo populations, which is regularly conducted by the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service. In recent years, it has expanded its capacity to do so because of the extraordinary controversy which develops every year about the approval of quotas for States for kangaroo culling. My general view, by the way, is that the National Parks and Wildlife Service is doing an excellent job in its monitoring of kangaroo populations. I have been more than happy to defend the Service against allegations from Greenpeace and other groups, even when it recommends that I approve Queensland programs. I can tell Senator Boswell that that is the litmus test of my faith in the National Parks and Wildlife Service's research into kangaroo populations.

Senator Puplick also referred to the north Queensland rainforests and the cuts in CSIRO funds in that respect. Again, I point out that the CSIRO is but one organisation conducting research into tropical rainforests. In fact, the Government funded a consultancy by Aila Keto's outfit-the Rainforest Conservation Society of Queensland. That was used extensively by the Government in its case for listing those rainforests for World Heritage.

Senator Puplick referred to rabbits, which are a big problem-in fact, it is one of Australia's great problems and it receives far too little attention. It is interesting to note that in July this year, at the meeting of the Australian and New Zealand environment councils in Nelson, New Zealand, we were given an extensive briefing on the rabbit plague. The briefing was, in fact, given by people from the CSIRO who were undertaking research in this area. They highlighted one property in South Australia on which there were 24 million rabbits. In looking at the problem, they referred to the possibility of biological control with a disease that has spread from Mexico to China and into Italy. Apparently, that is a source of great hope. Obviously, that research is well under way, and certainly the scientists present who were briefing us were not complaining about the extent of resources.

We must consider as well the present problem-and it will be a problem possibly in the next century or two-of the ozone layer and the greenhouse effect. So there has been an enormous increase in Government funding for research; it is just that all the funding is not going to the CSIRO. While I can understand the CSIRO being peeved about that, the Bureau of Meteorology is not so peeved as it has received a very substantial increase for which I think it is grateful. I use those examples only to illustrate the fact that, in the field of environmental research, there is a whole range of institutes, universities and government organisations that are undertaking research.

The statement by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) on the environment, from which Senator Puplick quoted, referred to a whole raft of bodies that receive very substantial extra funds for environmental research. The Biological Resources Study-an important and underrated area of environmental research in Australia-has produced, even in the last 12 months, some extraordinary results, and it will produce more as a result of what the Prime Minister announced. In addition, I refer to the Australian environmental resources information network which will provide us with a database that will finally, I hope, supply the information base necessary to make the most important environmental decisions. The Heritage Commission conducts research into wilderness inventories and that research is continuing. My point is that a whole range of areas-whether the Office of the Supervising Scientist, the National Parks and Wildlife Service, the Biological Resources Study or a number of others-have received greatly increased funds for environmental research.

I cannot, and do not, claim to have conducted a total inventory or weighed up what the CSIRO claims to have lost as against improvements in other environmental research areas. However, if I were a betting man, I would wager that the improvements far outweigh the losses, and I have mentioned only a few of them. I was also asked about the Antarctic Centre. If I have missed any question, I hope honourable senators will tell me. I cannot recall the Commonwealth ever pledging itself to the Antarctic Centre. I know that some arrangements have been made at a State level; certainly, former Premier Gray gave the matter a fairly high priority. As I have said, I cannot recall the Commonwealth ever pledging itself to this Centre. Certainly, I have never been party to a decision which involved that. I have never put forward a submission to Cabinet on it and had it dealt with successfully. I cannot recall anything about it. I do not think the Commonwealth has broken any promise on the matter or backed away from any undertaking. Any further questions on the Antarctic Centre would more properly be addressed to the Tasmanian Government, and I am not certain how it would respond.

Next, Senator Puplick referred to, in his words, the total failure of the Department of the Arts, Sport the Environment, Tourism and Territories to provide reports. I would like to read, rather than table, a fairly short letter, as I hope it effectively answers Senator Puplick's queries. It is from Susan Gibb, one of my private secretaries, to Peter Hamburger, Secretary of Estimates Committee D. The letter states:

May I, on behalf of the Department of the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories, express our appreciation for Estimates Committee D's comment upon the Department's diligence in providing prompt responses to questions on notice.
It is always good in such letters to have some praise first. The letter continues:
There is however-
this is normally the next line-
one matter which does concern me.

That Committee commented that the failure to provide ``advance copies of the annual reports'' breached the ``legal obligation to report to Parliament''. As you will recall, we discussed providing to the Committee copies of drafts of annual reports in September, some time before the hearings.

My record of our conversation is that I advised you that it was unlikely that the drafts would be ready. Your reply was to the effect that the request was formal only and they were not needed. With the benefit of hindsight, it seems unfortunate neither I nor the Department was advised that the Committee particularly wanted the reports and considered there to be legal obligation to provide advance copies of the reports.

I would be grateful if you would circulate this letter to the members of the Estimates Committee D so that they might be advised that the Department did not deliberately fail to meet its obligations to report to the Parliament. Rather, in view of our conversation, the Department and other portfolio agencies were under the impression that the Committee merely had expressed an interest in obtaining copies of drafts of the annual reports only if they were readily available.

In view of that letter, it is difficult to sustain this claim of total failure of the Department, as expressed by Senator Puplick. The reality is that the provision of reports is always subject to gaining certificates from the Auditor-General which, I might say, in this day and age is not an easy process. It is something that the Department attempts on every occasion but is not always possible to achieve.

I understand that, even in the absence of an Auditor-General's certificate, there are obligations on us. But, having said that, I can say that my office, in its contact with the Committee, attempted to establish clearly what the Committee regarded as our proper obligations, and I do not believe that we departed from our understanding of those obligations and of what the Committee actually required. If we have done so, I can undertake to make sure that it never happens again. However, we thought we clearly understood the Committee's requirements and my clear understanding was that we had abided by that undertaking.

TALK.START.PARA: —Because of the great respect that I have for the Department of the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories and the way in which it has dealt with Estimates committees in the past and, indeed, because of my own knowledge of Dr Gibb and what she would have committed to paper, all I can say is that if the facts are as set out in Dr Gibb's letter there is a very considerable question as to the service which the Estimates Committee has been given by its secretary. It is a matter which I shall now take up with either the Chairman of the Committee or the Clerk of the Senate because if that account, according to what the Minister has said and what Dr Gibb has committed to her letter, is correct, in my view it represents gross dereliction of duty by somebody and I propose to make sure that I establish precisely by whom.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to raise a couple of matters relating to the National Film and Sound Archive. No doubt, Mr Chairman, if you were not in the chair you might well be raising them yourself. They relate to an additional response by Senator Richardson late this afternoon in which he corrected a comment which had indicated that there may be increased funding becoming available to the Sound and Film Archive when, in fact, it now appears that funding is not becoming available. The reason I raise this is that there is clear concern in the printed replies to questions asked at the Senate Estimates Committee relating to the adequacy of the funds available to the National Film and Sound Archive to preserve the nitrate stock of film which is deteriorating rapidly. I raise this because, it seems to me, there is a clear indication in these written replies that the present funding is inadequate.

SPEECH.PARA: At one stage in the printed responses to a question by Senator Hamer the Department said:

These resources are adequate only to cope with that component of the nitrate film collection which is at immediate risk of decomposition during those four years. Additional resources would be required to provide for the remainder of the at-risk nitrate film collection still awaiting copying.
There is then a response as follows:

Resources need to be maintained at the present level until the entire nitrate film collection is copied. Extra laboratory facilities and storage would be required to cope with this part of the Archive's collection.
This becomes a little more confusing when one looks further on and sees the clear statement that the funding is inadequate to cope. The printed statement on page 9 states:

Based on known rates of decomposition it can be assumed that all nitrate films ought to be copied by the year 2000. At the current rate of special funding for nitrate preservation, the Australian component of the collection could all be preserved by the year 2005.

That is five years later than the time that the National Film and Sound Archive says all the nitrate film should be copied. I do not know what the Government thinks will happen during those five years-perhaps, magically, decomposition will cease. There is clearly, in these written replies, a statement of major concern about a five-year excessive time delay between treating this nitrate stock and the time that it ought to be treated.

The current backlog in processing nitrate material is three staff years, or approximately 700,000 feet of film to be examined and assessed for film preservation. However, the Archive seems to me to go on to raise even greater problems. It states of the current year:
Target figures for copying of motion picture film materials during the 1989/90 financial year are:
(i) Nitrate based film materials-280,000 feet copied to acetate for preservation.
(ii) Acquisition exchange-240,000 feet of nitrate and 400,000 feet of acetate to be examined and, if accepted for addition to the collection to have video copies made for delivery to suppliers.
The key point is that, of the present stock, only 280,000 feet are to be copied to acetate for preservation. The report goes on to state:
This will bring the total amount of nitrate based picture film preserved onto acetate based film to approximately 2 million feet or-
I want to stress this-
17% of the total nitrate collection. This will leave some 83% of the nitrate film collection for preservation.

In other words, more than four-fifths of the job is still ahead of us by the end of this financial year. There is an admission that apparently we will be five years too late in terms of the target date by which this ought to be done, and nothing is being done to speed it up. These figures clearly indicate that approximately 10 million feet will remain to be done by the target year of 2000. It would take just under a million feet a year to be processed and this year, I point out, 280,000 feet are being processed, not a million feet. If this is to be delayed until 2005 it makes an annual rate of approximately 600,000 feet. In other words, we look to be going at a rate that is clearly 50 per cent too slow to meet the target date.

TALK.START.PARA: —No.

—The Minister shakes his head and says no. Maybe the Minister has a special way of doing sums. I know he is good at numbers, and his Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) has had to rely on him for numbers in the past. The fact is, and I direct the Minister's attention to it, that if 17 per cent represents approximately two million feet, then 83 per cent represents approximately 10 million feet, and the Minister can work that out on his fingers. To preserve 10 million feet by the year 2000, as I said, will need 900,000 feet a year. The current rate, which the Department says is acceptable to reach the target of the year 2005, is approximately 600,000 feet. The difference between 600,000 and 900,000 is 300,000, which is 50 per cent. The Minister now is actually finding out that that sum is right.
—No, I am not.
—The difference between 600,000 and 900,000 is 300,000, and 300,000 of 600,000 is 50 per cent. Even the Minister might have to acknowledge that fact.

SPEECH.PARA: I stress this real concern which has emerged from the written replies and ask the Minister-in view of his response today that no additional funding is being provided to cope with what is clearly a crisis-when will the Government recognise and act on the clear statement, which I draw to his attention once again, from his own Archive that the film ought to be copied by the year 2000 but, at the present rate, it will not be copied until the year 2005.

TALK.START.PARA: —Whilst not making too much of a quibble, the words `responsible' and `Minister of the Hawke Government' are opposites and irreconcilable. I look forward to a situation in which our Minister in the new Peacock government after the next election will fix up this mess.

SPEECH.PARA: The dispute was one of the factors the ATC took into account when it drew up its visitor arrival targets for the next decade.

. . . the New Zealand market cannot be taken for granted. A slowdown in visitor arrivals in early 1989 led to a growth rate of 6.9 per cent for 1988-89 . . . The slowing in growth emphasised the need for fresh and innovative marketing techniques.

There is no doubt that in any event Australia is facing a tourism problem, fuelled by increasing Australian costs, despite some very imaginative work by the Australian Tourist Commission in an attempt to attract tourists. Certainly, they predict very substantial growth by the year 2000, no doubt based on the assumption that the pilots strike will be over by the year 2000. I would like the Minister to let us know what assumptions in terms of the pilots strike were used by the Department and the Tourist Commission in setting these very demoralising and depressing targets for 1989 and 1990 which predict minimal or no growth over the next two years compared to the bounding growth of last year. Is it not about time that the Government did something positive to resolve the pilots dispute if that is the major issue, or did something positive to halt inflation if, as seems to be the case, that is the major issue?

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Baume has shown an awful ignorance of the industry in his contribution this evening. When one looks at the cost structure of Australian holidays for international visitors there have been some alarming cost increases in the last couple of years. When I had actual day to day responsibility for the industry I made a number of public pleas in speeches to some of the leading hotels around Australia, particularly those in Sydney and Melbourne, not to increase their prices at the rate at which they were. The rate of increase in prices for the major hotels in Sydney is an example of this. It bears no resemblance to inflation. It leaves inflation for dead. There is no comparison.

SPEECH.PARA: The years of plenty were brought about by a forward thinking Hawke Government which came in and picked up tourism, which had been for so long ignored by the Fraser Government, massively increased funding for the Australian Tourist Commission (ATC) and did something about attracting visitors. One can only assume that, having done that, and the industry having enjoyed the benefits of those far-sighted actions, for which I must give my predecessor John Brown great credit, the industry decided that things would be good forever. Some of those in the industry took great advantage of that. Expo and the Bicentennial brought home to them just how good things could be, and they had a blow-out. Unfortunately, the costs of the major hotels in some of our capital cities blew out with it. That caused the industry a problem then and, in my view, causes it one now.

Having said that, I think we should return to the real thrust of Senator Michael Baume's comments. When he was not playing politics he was actually asking some questions. TALK.START.PARA: —It is not a dispute!

If the Tourist Commission is still using that phrase in its publications, then I correct it now. The difficult situation with the pilots in recent times has caused us some problems. Given that I mentioned my foray into London, it is interesting to note that, at the function which the Australian Tourist Commission had for the one day that I was there, representatives of the industry in Great Britain had come along in fairly great numbers. I attempted, in so far as is possible on occasions of this kind, to talk to as many of them as I could. Some were saying that a drop of 15 per cent in numbers coming to Australia from the United Kingdom and Ireland-which, of course, have been our star performers of foreign markets in the last 12 months-was likely over the course of the next three months. I cannot say that that was a universally held view, but it certainly seemed to be a majority view from what I could glean.
—What about the months after three?

—I think after those three months it will depend upon our capacity to demonstrate that that difficult situation is difficult no longer. If we can demonstrate that, then I am confident that our numbers can go back up. But there is a question of confidence about the capacity of international visitors to fly internally in Australia without discomfort. We will have to satisfy the questions involved in that if we are to get the numbers back up. That was the purpose of my visit to London and I hope I contributed, at least in some small way, to that process.

SPEECH.PARA: I wish just to add a couple of other comments to that. September visitor arrivals show a decline of about 17 per cent over the previous year. Holiday arrivals show a decline in that month of about 22 per cent. Obviously we can attribute some of that to a decline over the extraordinary year of 1988 with Expo and the Bicentennial. But, having said that, it is still a significant decline and a worry for Australia. I do not believe that the full impact of the difficult situation we have experienced with the pilots is reflected in just the September figures. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Committee is considering a department which is hydra-headed. My cousin, Senator Michael Baume, has just been discussing tourism. I wish to direct some remarks now to territories, particularly the Australian Capital Territory and to the Royal Canberra Hospital in the Australian Capital Territory. I raised this matter during the examination of Senate Estimates Committee F. The matter did not properly belong there. Being the Royal Canberra Hospital, it properly belongs in this Committee and in this group. The problem concerns the human immuno-deficiency virus (HIV) which as honourable senators know causes the disease acquired immune deficiency syndrome (AIDS). It concerns the national policy which we have developed in this country for dealing with that infection.

SPEECH.PARA: I remind members of the Committee that we have two elements to our national policy: the first is to prevent infection of people with the virus; the second is to minimise damage done by the virus to those who are infected. I want to report to the Committee on action by the Royal Canberra Hospital staff that was not in the best interests of patients, that was contrary to the national policy that has been developed by this Government and promoted by this Government, and that was quite contrary to all of the guidelines that have been laid down. After it was raised in the Estimates Committee, when I phoned the hospital to see what it had done about the problem, I discovered that hospital staff were obdurate in their determination to go down a road which was inappropriate and incorrect.

The facts are that there are only certain ways in which to pick up the human immuno-deficiency virus. Normal contact, including nursing someone who is infected, is not one of those ways. Further, when a patient is admitted to the Royal Canberra Hospital-as a certain patient whom I mentioned in Estimates Committee F was; I refer honourable senators and members of the Committee to page F161 and the following pages of the Hansard of 10 October-who is negative on blood tests and is not infected with the virus, there is absolutely no reason in the world to consider that patient to be dangerous to the staff. After all, if someone is not infected that person will not pass on the virus.

I want to report the case of a patient admitted to the Royal Canberra Hospital for suspected meningitis, a patient who was open and candid enough to say that he was homosexual but who could report, and whose doctor could report, that numerous blood tests had shown that he was not carrying the virus that causes HIV infection, who was then treated by staff at the Royal Canberra Hospital as a high risk patient. By the way, there is no such thing as a high risk patient, there is high risk behaviour. A red sticker was placed on the record at the end of his bed saying `high risk'. Nurses wore gloves and masks when they came to take his temperature or to tend him. He said that his bed linen was not changed for three days.

All in all the hospital staff behaved disgracefully. We have actually got certain things laid down in the national policy which was released by this Government-I seem to recall that Dr Blewett and Mr Shack together released the policy as a bipartisan matter because it is too important for party politics. First, we laid down the right to confidentiality. What kind of confidentiality did this patient get in the Royal Canberra Hospital with a great red sticker on the end of his bed saying `high risk' when he was not a high risk patient and when it was inappropriate behaviour in any case? Confidentiality as laid down in the policy was breached. Secondly, he was treated inappropriately because there was absolutely no need for nursing staff to wear gloves or masks unless they were doing it for every patient in the hospital, as someone pointed out in the Estimates Committee. Of course they were not.

It indicates that in the Royal Canberra Hospital at that time, a little earlier this year, there was gross ignorance on the part of line staff about the proper cross-infection control measures to be applied for the prevention of HIV infection. Obviously there was ignorance of the infection control measures which have been identified and publicised for control of HIV infection-and they have been identified. The Australian National Council on AIDS has done so. There was grossly inappropriate behaviour towards this particular patient. That was bad enough. I have to pay tribute to the Department of Community Services and Health. When this matter was raised-I must say improperly raised by me-Senator Cook was the Minister in that Committee and he did not object. The Department promised to raise it with the Royal Canberra Hospital. The Chief Medical Officer had this exchange with me. I said:
You said earlier that, if you became aware of a State or Territory hospital not abiding by those guidelines, you would be in touch with it.
That was my question. The Chief Medical Officer, Dr Adams, replied:

Certainly. We have a governmental committee on AIDS, a member of which would be the Chief Health Officer for the ACT. We can take that up with him immediately to see what is happening in Canberra hospitals.

This happened on 10 October. I was outraged. We are having enough difficulty in this community to stop hysterical over-reaction to human immuno-deficiency virus infection. It is made much worse if someone comes in demonstrably not infected, who just happens to be homosexual and is treated in this manner. By the way, for those who do not know, about 10 per cent of males in Australia are homosexual. Unless red stickers are to be placed on the beds of 10 per cent of all patients, this is obviously grossly irresponsible, improper and inappropriate behaviour by the Royal Canberra Hospital.

Following this exchange on 10 October and knowing that Dr Adams would have been as good as his word, one would have thought that the Chief Health Officer for the ACT would have been advised. One could have hoped that at that hospital something would have been done. We know that policy direction on this matter has to come from the top. If we are dealing with businesses, we have to convince the board. If we are dealing with national policy, we have to convince the Cabinet. If we are dealing with a hospital, we have to convince the hospital management. I said that this happened on 10 October. On 25 October, knowing that this committee stage debate was coming up, I decided to phone the Royal Canberra Hospital to see what might have happened.

First of all, I discovered that the Executive Officer was away on some perfectly proper activity. I could not get on to the Executive Officer but I made some inquiries and on 26 October a phone call was received in my office. It was from a secretary to Judith Robson who is the Acting Executive Officer of the hospital in the absence of the Executive Officer. She said, `I am phoning about the high risk patient'. That indicates that the secretary to the Chief Executive Officer had learned nothing in the fortnight-nothing, not a single thing-because the patient was not a high risk patient. Why did the secretary keep saying that she had rung about the high risk patient? My staff officer replied-we have recorded the conversation, of course-`You mean Mr Young, who is not a high risk patient'. Incidentally, I identified the name of the patient only because he had already identified himself publicly in another publication. So my staff officer said, `Do you mean Mr Young, who is not a high risk patient?'. The secretary to the Acting Chief Executive Officer said, `Yes, Mr Young, the high risk patient'. We were trying to help her. We were trying to give her the signal that he was not a high risk patient. But if we cannot get the management or the Chief Executive Officer in the hospital to understand something about the principles of this illness, God help the rest of the hospital. If we cannot get the Royal Canberra Hospital to understand this illness, God help the Canberra community.

At present in Australia we have recorded 1,500 people with AIDS. By 1995 we can expect to have 15,000 recorded cases and maybe 150,000 infected people. It will touch all our lives. Every one of us will know, will be dealing with, will be relating to, will be caring for and will be worrying about someone who is infected. We will not do it if we do not understand what the illness is about. My staff member responded and said, `He is not a high risk patient', to which the secretary then responded, `Anyway, I am phoning back for Acting Chief Executive Officer, Judith Robson, who said to phone Mr Wayne Berry's office in a couple of days. They could not help with any inquiries about high risk patients'. So we have an obdurate, obstinate refusal, at the most senior levels of the Royal Canberra Hospital, to teach their own office staff what in the name of goodness this infection is about.

I would like to get an acknowledgment from the Government that what I have said and what I am complaining about is consistent with the policy we have laid down. Of course, we want to prevent infection but we also want to ameliorate the adverse effects of the infection. What we are seeing here is the adverse effects being applied to someone who is not infected. This is scapegoating of the worst kind. It is incompetence and I suggest that we should expect better from the Royal Canberra Hospital and every other health institution.

Let me say a few words in defence of the hospital. We have been dealing with the administrative head of the hospital. Had I gone to certain of the clinical departments I might have got a completely different answer. When this patient was admitted, the clinicians were in charge of his treatment and put the red sticker on his bed and the clinical nurses decided to don gloves and masks to treat him. My concern is that we go in very hard, early, to try to get our policy right and to get it understood. That means having our major health care institutions understanding and applying it as it should be applied. What went on at this hospital to this man was awful.

Honourable senators and members of the Committee would be interested to know that this man wrote an account of his mistreatment for a journal called AIDS Action which is published by the AIDS Action Council of the Australian Capital Territory. In the August 1989 issue he concluded his article by advising people in the ACT in the following terms:

I for one, however, as a result of my recent experience, would strongly advise any person to conceal they are gay, (or an intravenous drug user), especially if they are confident of being HIV negative until procedures at Royal Canberra Hospital are changed.

He is absolutely right. If the consequences of admitting something about one's personal lifestyle are that one is treated in that fashion, one would be a fool to let people know. The Government and the Opposition have worked together. We have gone to a lot of trouble to try to develop a policy which is appropriate and proper. It is a pity that it is not being applied more consistently or more expertly within the ACT.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Peter Baume intervened in this debate not by asking a question but by making a statement and several accompanying observations which I think it would be improper for the Government not to acknowledge and reply to. In Estimates committee hearings and in debates such as this in the Committee of the Whole, the Government sometimes receives complaints that the procedures of Estimates committees, and the way in which they are practised or undertaken, are misused. This is not the occasion on which I would make that complaint; this is an occasion on which I would say that the vehicle of the Committee of the Whole has proved useful in enabling Senator Peter Baume to ventilate a matter of concern to him and, I believe, to the Government and the wider community as well. I take this moment to acknowledge that.

SPEECH.PARA: I also want to say that Senator Peter Baume-he was modest enough not to refer to it-was a medical practitioner of some distinction before he entered politics. We in the Government would rather that he continued as a medical practitioner because he adds firepower and weight to the Opposition. Nonetheless, he speaks on this matter in this forum with that background and knowledge.

We are dealing with the estimates of departments considered by Estimates Committee D. The matter Senator Peter Baume has raised arises under the territories division of these estimates-a conglomerate portfolio which is before the chamber at the moment. It so happens, by good luck, poor management, or a combination of both, that I am the Minister representing the Minister for Community Services and Health (Dr Blewett). Later tonight or tomorrow we will take the estimates for Estimates Committee F, in which the community services and health portfolio appears, where this question equally could have been asked.

It is not offensive to the proposition that has been mounted but, from a territory portfolio point of view, it is appropriate to make the observation that these matters concerning the Royal Canberra Hospital fall outside the purview of the territory portfolio as such. That view cannot be put as strongly, although there are elements of truth in it for the community services and health portfolio. I will treat the remarks raised this evening by Senator Peter Baume as questions on notice for me to answer tomorrow in full expectation, rightly, that this issue should be answered. However, before yielding to the portfolio Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories, Senator Richardson, I regard the events as recounted-events of which I have had some knowledge-as forming a particularly tacky and tasteless affair. They are events which elevate ignorance to a level that is undeserving. In the face of better knowledge, the dogged persistence to stick with the high risk patient category defies understanding.

The other point I wish to make is that it is vitally important for the community to be able to contend with the effects of AIDS and with those who are infected, honestly and directly, without making proscriptive moral judgments and by going directly to the cause and treating that cause in the best possible way. That means that, if people come forward under medical attention and declare their sexual preference-in this case, that they are homosexual-that should be respected as an indication to others that they should too, so that there is a broader understanding in the medical fraternity about what may be the possible causes of any problems, if that be the case. For someone to be penalised, as it would seem in this case, for simply being honest is to invite people not to declare their preferences and thus endanger the whole potential treatment regime that might apply. If nothing else, apart from the behavioural aspects of this particular case, that is the most enduring and damaging testimonial to these events.

SPEECH.PARA: I am not here to defend the international hotels. Most of them have fewer than 100 rooms and their tariffs are certainly less than $100. Any increase in tariffs that they may have added have only been to match the high cost structures enforced by this Government as a result of interest rates and inflation. They have not had their snouts in the trough. It is a highly competitive industry at that particular level. They cater not only for Australian tourists but for international tourists as well. It is a highly competitive industry and they certainly cannot afford the great hikes that the international hotels have been able to make.

Was the Minister referring to these people? Of course he was, because he does not understand the industry at all. Are we to believe that the Minister is saying that these people are rip-off merchants? He has been so spoilt in going from international hotel to international hotel that he simply has no understanding of the small business structure of this particular industry. The Minister suggests that the tariffs are so high that the tourists can no longer afford to stay. Again, I come back to the simple point: he knows only the international circuit. Will the Minister please withdraw his comments, or at least enlighten us as to exactly what he meant by those comments?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALKER.NAME: Senator RICHARDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories)

TALK.START.PARA: —I made some comments earlier about the major hotels mainly in Sydney and Melbourne, and to some extent in Brisbane-but especially Sydney. I have no intention whatsoever of backing away from any of those comments. They were, of course, all correct. I have waited here for a number of years to hear from Senator McGauran a contribution that involved passion, one that gave the sense that Senator McGauran really cared. Tonight my long wait came to an end. Tonight we actually heard some passion from Senator McGauran. I am delighted to think that it is possible. Senator McGauran showed that in the cause of self-interest nothing is impossible.
—I rise on a point of order, Madam Temporary Chairman. My point of order is that the Minister is improperly reflecting upon the motives of Senator McGauran. I ask that he withdraw.
—I think Senator Richardson is perhaps bordering on something unparliamentary.

—I will withdraw if it is a problem. Senator McGauran is one who has a background that is a little different from most of ours. Senator McGauran has done pretty well. He is one of those who have done extraordinarily well-not, I might say, through any effort of his own. But, of course, he was born well.

—I rise on a point of order, Madam Temporary Chairman. Senator Richardson is reflecting on the character of Senator McGauran. He is relying on a personal attack on Senator McGauran. Senator McGauran brought up, quite properly, a defence of the industry. Senator Richardson is using a personal attack and is attacking Senator McGauran's background. I believe that is unparliamentary and I ask you to call him to order.
—On the point of order: one wonders how it is unparliamentary to suggest that someone was born well.
—It was the tone of the voice used when you said it.
—Oh, the tone of the voice!
—That is not a point of order.

—It is very difficult to withdraw the tone. As I was saying before I was rudely interrupted, Senator McGauran was born well. He enjoyed a life of privilege. (Quorum formed) As I was saying before the quorum was called, Senator McGauran enjoyed a life of privilege. He did very well.

—I again rise on a point or order, Madam Temporary Chairman. It is beyond Senator Richardson's understanding to know what sort of lifestyle Senator McGauran enjoyed or did not enjoy. I think the Chair would agree that Senator McGauran has the right to some sort of privacy in his lifestyle. Senator Richardson is making allegations that he cannot possibly substantiate.
—There is no point of order, Senator Boswell.

—As I was saying, Senator McGauran enjoyed a particularly privileged lifestyle. I am told on very reliable authority that this was caused by the family's interest in hotels. So when Senator McGauran rises in the chamber on a point about hotels, and certainly about hotel profits, he knows more than I; about drinking on the other side of the bar, he knows very little. I do not know enough. I have sought over the years to make up for this knowledge gap. But I must say that--

—I raise a point of order, Madam Temporary Chairman. Perhaps you might be able to direct me-this may be a point of misrepresentation. When the Minister indicates that I know nothing about drinking on either side of the bar, he shows a distinct lack of knowledge of my family. We have had hotels for over 70 years. I have not only drunk on one side of the bar but I have served on the other side.
—There is no point of order, Senator McGauran. If you have a personal explanation to make, you will have an opportunity to do so later.
—I am delighted to hear that Senator McGauran has acknowledged that the family has had hotels for 70 years.
—More.

—More than 70 years. I did not know that it was that long. I am delighted to think that these hotels have given Senator McGauran all that he has had over the years. It is a pity that he could bring so little here. But I would say, after listening to his comments on the hotel industry, that he does have a knowledge of a particular kind of hotel. I made some comments about the big international hotels in Sydney and Melbourne, the hotels visited by the Americans and the Japanese. I stand by those comments. That Senator McGauran would be so moved to protect the family's income surprises me nought. That he has failed so dismally surprises me even less. That he would continue to do so would be the first thing that he has done that would ever surprise me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a separate issue with the Minister in respect of which he can attribute to me no personal motive other than the magnificent--
—If Walshie were here, he would; he would find a way.

—Of course he would-absolutely. He represents all those sorts of things about the Australian Labor Party that cause people to put it last on the ballot paper. I am not capable of saying anything unkind about anybody from the other side of the chamber. I had to muster up some sort of indignation just to say that much. I raise with the Minister some matters in respect of the inquiry of the Standing Committee on the Environment, Recreation and the Arts into drugs in sport, of which I have the dubious distinction of being the Deputy Chairman. The Committee has made a number of recommendations in respect of testing by an independent agency, the criminalisation of the use of anabolic steroids and the upgrading of surveillance by the Australian Customs Service. I ask the Minister to forgive me for not having asked these questions at the Estimates Committee hearing but I was just not available. I will understand if the Minister is not able to give me detailed answers.

SPEECH.PARA: Is it the view of the Government that the recommendations that are contained in the Committee's report ought to be adopted? We understand that the Minister has embraced the proposal for an independent agency. I understand he has indicated that publicly and we thank him for that. Legislative procedures are necessary to implement fully that recommendation. Could the Minister give me an indication as to when we might see that legislation? Provided the Government accepts the recommendation-and I understand it does-when will the Commonwealth and State Ministers meet to look at some of the responsibilities we suggest that they should assume. One might reasonably argue, with the non-dispute that is going on with the pilots, that there is some difficulty in that. Can the Minister give me an idea as to when we might see some action in respect of that? In the event that that meeting is consummated, can we expect that recommendation 10 will be dealt with? Recommendation 10 states:
(i) agree to make anabolic steroids prepared for human use a Schedule Eight drug;
(ii) agree to make the sale or supply without prescription of anabolic steroids a criminal offence, using the Western Australian legislation as a model;

(iii) subject to advice from Commonwealth and State Ministers for primary industry, and because of the widespread use of veterinary anabolic steroids by sportspeople, investigate the possibility of making veterinary anabolic steroids subject to the same degree of control as applies to anabolic steroids for human use.

In particular I refer to point (iii) because, while I think some States are amending their legislation-or at least introducing new legislation-to overcome the problem, we had the experience during our Committee deliberations of learning, for instance, that it is inappropriate and an offence, in fact, to provide or administer anabolic steroids to race horses but that it is appropriate to supply the same anabolic steroids to human beings which, by any measure, is a contradiction in terms of one's standards of health and welfare. I will leave it at that for the time being. Could the Minister give me an indication of his present position?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALKER.NAME: Senator RICHARDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Crichton-Browne mentioned the question of upgrading Customs surveillance. I am not able to provide any information on that matter now. It will have to be checked. In so far as the legislation on the Australian Sports Drug Agency is concerned, as the honourable senator would be aware, the body is already up and running and is being overseen at present by a committee from the Australian Sports Commission. Legislation is currently being prepared. I would not imagine that we would be able to deal with it in the Senate before the New Year, but it certainly will be a priority of mine to convince my colleagues that it is priority legislation for the next session. That legislation will provide for a committee, which will be outside the Sports Commission, to oversee that body. As the honourable senator would know, we have physically removed the body, but we will also take away that oversight role.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable senator then raised the question of action by the Commonwealth-State Ministers on the criminalisation, if that is a correct word, of the administering of anabolic steroids. I raised this matter at a meeting of sports Ministers last June, I think, and there was unanimous support from all States for that position. We were to have another meeting on 13 November. The pilots situation and the fact that I was in the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics led to that meeting not going ahead. It will be held very soon. I would be looking to some progress reports from the States to see where they are up to. I have not had any. I am waiting for the meeting to get them. I am not aware of what they have done on the question of veterinary surgeons perhaps finding steroids they could divert to humans. That is something we will have to raise with them and get their response to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Panizza Sen J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before I raise the recommendations of the Senate Committee on Environment, Recreation and the Arts inquiry into drugs in sport, I wish to pick up on a point made by the Minister earlier this evening. While he was talking about tourism he spoke of the airlines being able to fly people around Australia quite comfortably at present. Obviously, he has not flown on the 757 which Ansett Airlines of Australia has borrowed, I think, from a Spanish airline. The seats on it are as hard as concrete. Having spent four hours on it from midnight, Perth time, Perth to Sydney, I can hardly sit down. The other 230 people who were on that crowded aeroplane would be in the same position. Before the Minister makes further statements like that-innocently as it may have been-he should check the suitability of that plane for long distances.

SPEECH.PARA: I turn to the drugs in sport inquiry. Senator Crichton-Browne has mentioned a couple of its recommendations. One recommendation is that the Australian Institute of Sport investigate the approval of medical supply purchases without medical officer authorisation, contrary to AIS policy. There was a lot of evidence presented to the Committee that medical supplies were bought under the orders of a coach without having been okayed by the doctors. There is a recommendation from Price Waterhouse, which did an inquiry into the books of the AIS. It states:

In our view, there has been and will always be scope for unscrupulous persons to misuse Institute funds and would point out that, given the nature of the Institute's operations, it would be virtually impossible to devise a failsafe scheme, particularly with regard to travel expenditure.

A lot of questions were raised at the inquiry as to the acquittal of expenses where coaches and others were taking money overseas. Senator Black is in the chamber. He should remember this. The expenses were not necessarily properly acquitted when people returned. The question I address to the Minister based on that recommendation and on previous recommendations is: What has the Department done to make sure that such handling of money never happens again? One coach at the AIS wrote out a receipt to himself in one case. In other words, he was acquitting money to himself. In another case, the Institute, under the guise of the coach or the other way around, had got some stuff from a pharmacy in New South Wales. The coach was so negligent in covering up his tracks that he put down the pharmacy as having a Victorian address. I know that all of these things are water under the bridge, but I should certainly like to know whether measures have been put into place by the Department to carry out the recommendations that the Committee made on drugs in sport and to prevent these things from ever happening again. The people of Australia must have confidence that the AIS is being run properly.

Whilst I am on the subject of the AIS, a certain coach called Lyn Jones got quite a mention in the report. I would like to know whether he is still employed at the Institute; if he is employed, what his position is, what sort of salary he is on and what access he has to funds generally.

TALK.START.PARA: —He is a US health officer.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALKER.NAME: Senator RICHARDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories)

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Jones, to whom Senator Panizza just referred, declined to seek reappointment and is no longer employed by the Australian Institute of Sport. Apparently, Senator Crichton-Browne has some idea of where he is; I do not.
—I think he has been employed by the American Olympic squad, or some such thing, to give them some sort of advice, which supports my worst fears.

—And some of mine. In any event, he is not employed by the AIS, so I do not claim any responsibility for whatever he is doing. Obviously, the inquiry which has been conducted revealed a number of shortcomings in the way the Institute handled certain matters. In particular, reference was made to the Price Waterhouse internal audit report on the weightlifting expenditure. That report was carried out with the period 1981 to 1988 as the period to be covered. In fact, in was the Institute of Sport which suggested that the Audit Office be requested to conduct its own examination of weightlifting expenditure.

SPEECH.PARA: The Australian Audit Office reported directly to the Committee and a copy of that report has been made available. A summary of the findings is reported in the Auditor-General's report on ministerial portfolios. In summary, the Auditor-General concluded that the scope and approach of the internal audit review was soundly based and that the report represented fairly the matters addressed and the findings of the review. Further, the Auditor-General concluded that the internal audit review was undertaken in an independent manner and that the present AIS systems are generally appropriate, considering the Institute's size. The report recommended areas for improvement, including stock and asset control, the acquittal of goods purchased overseas and controls over sponsorship in kind. Importantly, it detected no evidence of the misuse of funds.

In respect of those areas recommended for improvement the Institute has implemented the following measures: it has revised assets and stores control systems and procedures. Current indications are that the Audit Office is satisfied with these changes. It has revised travel procedures and made sure that we have implemented systems which incorporate improved control over cash advances and acquittal procedures. There are revised procedures for the purchase of medical supplies, including vitamins and food supplements. In particular, the Institute has attempted to marry the efforts of medical staff with sports science staff to make sure that those two bodies are communicating better about what they are prescribing for athletes. There has been some improvement in the control over goods provided as sponsorship in kind. There has been an ongoing problem in that area which is not easily overcome. If one looks at the nature of the arrangements which relate to individual sponsors, that is easy to understand. But improvements are occurring and we will keep working on it.

TALK.START.PARA: —In an answer that the Minister gave to Senator Crichton-Browne regarding an agency-I think he said-having been set up and running, will that body be the final body after legislation is passed or is it an interim set of persons, for want of a better word, to do the job until the legislation goes through after which others will be selected to fill the positions?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALKER.NAME: Senator RICHARDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government is endeavouring to set up a body which can continue after the legislation is passed and which will not necessarily have to be altered. But that is in so far as staff and procedure are concerned. What is not addressed at the moment and what cannot be addressed until we get the legislation is the question of a proper body to oversee the activities of the agency. That will not happen until we get legislation, which will be in the new year, and I hope that we can get a committee which will satisfy anyone. Its job, by the way, will not be to choose individual athletes for testing. That will still be the job of staff. However, it will be to ensure that justice is applied equally and fairly across all the sports bodies.

SPEECH.PARA: I point out to Senator Panizza that there are still questions to be answered in the legislation; for example, `What sort of reporting systems should there be on those who are found to have positive tests? Should they be made public? If so, when-immediately or after appeals? Should they simply notify the Minister or do they notify the Parliament?'. I can honestly say that I am still in discussion with a number of people about the best way to go on some of those matters. I am not necessarily convinced one way or the other. We will not get an answer to those questions until the new year.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not want to pursue this matter unduly and offer the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories (Senator Richardson) rhetorical questions, but he would know that this matter has been addressed with impeccable impartiality and bipartisan support for the duration of this laborious inquiry, which I hope has been fruitful in terms of its endeavours and the ultimate resolutions which have flowed from it. I thank the Minister for his response in respect of Customs. I hope that that is a matter that the Minister will address with some vigour. I noticed that Mr Bowman from the Australian Institute of Sport, on return from overseas with some athletes, was quite outraged when he and his athletes were asked whether or not they had anything to declare in respect of this matter. Perhaps he had not read carefully the recommendations of the inquiry.

SPEECH.PARA: The other thing I should say, by way of self-congratulation, is that it is not without significance to note that almost all major amateur sports in Australia-although I can never draw a distinction between amateur and professional in this day and age-have embraced the more significant of our recommendations in terms of drug testing.

TALK.START.PARA: —Almost all the professional sports have.

—Almost all the professional and amateur sports, and I think almost without exception, have embraced our recommendation for independent testing-notwithstanding the fact that every single one of them has given us an assurance that their sport is the least likely to be helped by anabolic steroids or any other performance enhancing drugs. But out of decency to their athletes they are going to have them tested. The point that we have all sought to make is that these tests are not to catch the cheats; as much as anything they are to ensure that the decent, honest and endeavouring athletes can be seen to be winning on their own merits so that they are not smeared and coloured by claims relating to use of performance enhancing drugs. One coach who came before us showed us all his athletes' records to demonstrate that they were not on drugs-because their records were worse than anyone else's. Is not that an indictment of where we are at?

SPEECH.PARA: The Minister would be aware of the Moscow conference, which was attended by Senator Black, together with another 119 delegates from some 34 countries, and there is the Rome meeting of 13 nations. The Moscow meeting was really to get a consensus at least-to use the expression the Minister used earlier on-to establish the facts. The Rome meeting is to try to get something of a more substantial nature settled. The Minister would know that on 8 December there is a meeting of representatives from the United Kingdom, New Zealand and Australia, which nations take the bulk of the Commonwealth Games medals. I think about 80 per cent of the medals are won by those countries. The proposal is to have a cross-testing scheme amongst those three nations. One would think that that would be an excellent forerunner to ensure proper, legitimate, independent and discrete testing of all nations by other nations. Did the Minister support the Moscow conference and does he support the Rome meeting? More particularly, is the Government fully embracing the proposals for the 8 December meeting?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALKER.NAME: Senator RICHARDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories)

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes is the answer, I think, to all questions the honourable senator has asked. On my visit to the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics (USSR) a couple of weeks ago I had an appointment with the Russian Minister for Sport, Mr Rusak. Certainly, he indicated that the USSR is very keen to ensure that independent drug testing is carried out on athletes around the world. I do not doubt the sincerity of the USSR's views on the matter. I think the people there are pretty keen to see it carried through. They proudly point out, of course, that it is not their athletes that are getting caught around the world with positive tests. However, they are keen and I think that will be followed up.

SPEECH.PARA: As to the Rome meeting to which Senator Crichton-Browne referred, I think so much of it that the very famous Senator Black will be sent over there, along with Steve Haynes, to represent our views. I think that in itself is testimony to how important we regard the matter. As far as the meeting on 8 December is concerned, we are enthusiastic about an agreement and I think an agreement now is pretty much a formality.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boswell Sen R.L.D.

TALK.START.PARA: -I refer to Christmas Island and to air services, which at the moment are not provided. About four to five months ago the Department of the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories advertised for a northern charter from Singapore to Christmas Island. At that stage two tenders came from Christmas Island, and those tenders were not successful. A few weeks ago officers of the Department in Perth announced that Amann Aviation had been awarded the contract for flights between Singapore, Christmas Island, Cocos (Keeling) Islands and Perth. I believe that the price then was $600 from Christmas Island to Singapore. That price then increased to $700 from Christmas Island to Singapore.

SPEECH.PARA: The problems that Amann Aviation had suffered led to the contract being cancelled by the Department. I believe that the plane actually made the trip only twice. On the second attempt to depart from Christmas Island the engines were smoking and oil had to be poured into the engines while people were watching. On the third attempt the plane was about six or seven hours late arriving on Christmas Island. The reason given was that the engines were shuddering so much that the plane had to be flown at a speed that would barely keep it in the air. On the fourth attempt there were no life jackets on board and the Civil Aviation Authority grounded the plane. During this time of non-service the price has increased from $860 return from Perth to $930. People were very lucky not to be involved in a very serious accident. What is the position now regarding flights between Christmas Island, the Cocos (Keeling) Islands, Singapore and Perth? I know that last Wednesday a Royal Australian Air Force Hercules was put on the Christmas Island, Cocos (Keeling) Islands, Singapore route. Mr Woodmore is very keen, with a consortium of Islanders, to form a company that will run its own charter service. Will the Government be prepared to give its blessing to that charter service run by a consortium of Islanders? It is ironical, but I understand that the local garage man who runs the local service station was the man who--

TALK.START.PARA: —Supplied the oil.

—He probably supplied the oil, but he also arranged a charter from Singapore to Christmas Island when Amann Aviation was unable to carry people. I find it slightly strange that the local garage man, obviously a free enterprise spirit, was able to organise a charter. Mr Woodmore is establishing on the island a $26m casino. With the United Credit Union Ltd of Perth and another Islander, Leah Wong, he is very interested in establishing a charter service that would fly from Cocos (Keeling) Islands to Christmas Island and then to Singapore and return the other way. Can the Minister say whether his Government would see anything wrong in letting this service out to tender? If those to whom I have referred were successful in tendering and put that charter service in place, would the Department of the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories then operate a Government charter to complete against the private company? If that happened, it would probably make this enterprise uneconomic.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALKER.NAME: Senator RICHARDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories)

TALK.START.PARA: —We would certainly not try to run a Government operation to defeat those people for the charter. We are anxious to get some kind of long term settlement of the problem. Since this operation began, the Department of the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories has gone to great lengths to keep air links going. As Senator Boswell probably realises, the arrangement with Australian Airlines Ltd was ending; I think it ended last July or August. Therefore, the Government was already looking at a replacement, prior to the difficult situation with the pilots arising.

SPEECH.PARA: At the time, the Department approached the Australian Federation of Air Pilots and asked it for a dispensation, which the pilots refused, despite the isolated location of Christmas Island. The Department requested the Royal Australian Air Force (RAAF) to make available aircraft and also sought alternative charter aircraft. However, the only way to try to resolve the problem was to seek expressions of interest in providing some sort of temporary service to the islands.

When the Department did that, a number of operators applied and, out of that process, Amann Aviation was successful. A number of those who tendered an expression of interest were unsuitable because of either the size of the aircraft or the kind of operation they wanted to run. The Department agreed to Amann taking on the job on the basis that the Civil Aviation Authority (CAA) and the Department of Transport and Communications were satisfied that the operator had all the approvals necessary. On that basis, the operation began. The Department of Transport and Communications agreed with the operator proposed by Amann conducting weekly charter services to the islands until 21 December this year, subject to all the necessary operational clearances from the Civil Aviation Authority being received.

On the basis of information provided by Amann, the CAA agreed to the operation of three flights each on a one-off basis. Following the initial information from Amann, the CAA requested additional information, which would have been necessary for the charter flights to operate in the longer term. This revealed that some of the earlier information provided by Amann was not correct, and on this basis the CAA refused Amann the necessary approvals to conduct further operations until it could provide extra information. As events unfolded, the company could not do so, so the Department cancelled the contract with Amann, I think last week.

That development leaves us in a difficult situation. In the interim we have requested the RAAF to assist us with flights, but that would at best provide only a very temporary solution. Obviously, these flights are important, not just for the movement of people but also for the provision of goods and supplies and staple requirements. There is no emergency service in terms of medical evacuations. If necessary, the Flying Doctor Service of Australia is available for an emergency.

We will have to ensure a more permanent arrangement. There is a difficulty in getting aircraft of the size required, as they are in very short supply. Thus, merely calling for expressions of interest does not guarantee success. If the local garage man or any other group of Christmas Islanders or Cocos Islanders can come up with the right plane, I wish they would do so so quickly, as we would be anxious to approve the service.

TALK.START.PARA: -I take it that the Government will continue to provide the service to Christmas Island and Cocos (Keeling) Islands by the Royal Australian Air Force until some other arrangements are found that will serve the 1,300-odd Christmas Islanders and 500 or 600 Cocos Islanders. Will the Government be prepared to guarantee to run that service until another arrangement can be entered into?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALKER.NAME: Senator RICHARDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories)

TALK.START.PARA: —I will guarantee to mount some sort of a service. I cannot yet guarantee the Royal Australian Air Force (RAAF) service. Although I am pushing very hard for it and am reasonably confident of getting it, I have no written confirmation that the RAAF will continue the service in the meantime. I can guarantee to maintain a service, but I am not sure whether or not that will be the RAAF service.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boswell Sen R.L.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I also want to raise the matter of Norfolk Island, the whole economy of which, as the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories (Senator Richardson) would be aware, is based on the tourist industry. The island is suffering from the pilots dispute, which the Minister will not acknowledge is a dispute. Whether it is a dispute or a disruption-call it what you like-Norfolk Island is having massive problems. I understand that two hotels have been shut down and a number of the businesses are suffering. The banks are being asked to carry businesses at present. The Norfolk Island people are in very serious trouble.

SPEECH.PARA: The Minister has spoken about a $31m package to encourage the tourist industry when the flights return to normal. I ask the Minister whether any of that $31m can be allocated to promote tourism and resurrect it to the important position it held before the altercation with the pilots.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is a good word; I will start to use it.

—I am trying to ask the Minister whether there is any way in which he can promote Norfolk Island as a tourist destination so that its economy can recover somewhat from the rapid losses occurring in the present circumstances.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALKER.NAME: Senator RICHARDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories)

TALK.START.PARA: —As Senator Boswell will be aware, there has been a downturn in tourism on Norfolk Island which has been taking place over quite some time-certainly before this difficult situation with the pilots arose. Obviously, the situation with the pilots will not have helped that-in fact, it will quite obviously have made it worse-but it must be acknowledged that Norfolk Island, at least, was having problems prior to that situation developing.

SPEECH.PARA: Since the dispute began the Department has placed a very high priority on ensuring that flights to and from Norfolk Island for both cargo and passengers are maintained. At present, the Royal Australian Air Force (RAAF) operates two regular scheduled Hercules services to the Island each week. These flights operate under East-West Ltd flight numbers, and supplement a weekly F28 jet service from Brisbane and Sydney, operated by East-West, three 737 services from Auckland each week and daily commuter flights operated by Norfolk Island Airlines. I understand that East-West will be putting on a second F28 from the middle of December, which will coincide with the announced withdrawal of the RAAF emergency services. Within a very short period of time the capacity for the carrying of passengers to and from Norfolk Island will be as good as it ever was but, I remind the chamber again, there had already been a significant downturn in Norfolk Island tourism. When considering the package, while it is true to say that no money is currently allocated specifically to Norfolk Island, I intend to make sure that some of it is spent in attempting to rehabilitate the industry there.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boswell Sen R.L.D.

TALK.START.PARA: -On 27 September 1989 in this House during the adjournment debate I raised a matter relating to the magnificent cathedral of Notre Dame in Amiens, France, which contains a chapel dedicated to the Australian soldiers of World War I who fought so bravely in the defence of France and, indeed, in saving France. An Australian flag is draped from the ceiling of the chapel. It was reported to me that this flag was in a state of disrepair and that this was not becoming of such a magnificent cathedral and such an honourable chapel which is dedicated to Australian soldiers. On that day I requested the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Senator Gareth Evans), who was in the House at that time and who I thought was the responsible Minister-it turns out that it is the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Mr Humphreys)-to inquire into that matter with a view to replacing the Australian flag. It was a very important request as it is a symbol of Australia so far from our own shores. Every visitor who goes to this magnificent cathedral, indeed the greatest in Europe, and passes by this chapel, has a sense of honour for Australia and Australian soldiers.

SPEECH.PARA: I am pleased to say this evening that I did receive a reply last week from the Minister, Mr Ben Humphreys, on this matter. The extent to which he answered my request is to be commended. I would like to read out three paragraphs of that letter just to illustrate the extent the Minister went to. I quote from the Minister's letter:

I am advised that an Australian flag has been made available to the Amiens Cathedral by our Australian Embassy in Paris. This was provided in sufficient time to enable the Archbishop to have the flag on display in the Chapel for Armistice Day.

I am further advised that our Defence Attache in Paris, Wing Commander Steinbeck, was to visit Amiens in the week ending 17 November and that he was going to personally check and ensure that the flag was once again in place.

There are, of course, a number of chapels, small museums and memorials to our Australian dead throughout France. I am, therefore, arranging for a small supply of Australian flags to be made available through the Defence Attache. I believe that this will assist in avoiding problems such as the one which you have raised on this occasion.
I ask the Minister for Local Government (Senator Reynolds), who is in the House, to relay my appreciation to the Minister for his promptness and complete action in this matter.
